Praefatio.	Preface. 
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I completed for you, O sons, this book, which is the last of medical science with its completion, and I reached the end in it from its expositions and its own statements, it seemed to me fitting to complete it for you with this Treatise which is a part of operation, that is, surgery by hand. 
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since operation by hand is laid low in our region and time completely lost, until perhaps the knowledge of it perished, and its trace was cut off, and there remained from it nothing except small descriptions in old books, which hands altered, and error and hesitation happened to them until its intentions were closed and its force extended: It seemed fitting to me to revive it with the ordering of this Treatise on it according to the way of exposition, declaration, and abbreviation; and to come with forms of instruments of cautery and the rest of the tools for the work; with what is done by addition from declarations and from the celerity of that which is necessary. 
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why a good craftsman of it with his hand is not found in our time is: because the art of medicine is long, and it is necessary for its author to practice before that in the science of anatomy, as Galen narrated, until he knows the functions of the members, and their forms, and their conjunction and separation, and has knowledge of the bones, nerves, and muscles, and their number, and their emergence, and veins pulsating and quiet, and the places of their exit.  
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And on account of that Hippocrates said, that a name with a name is much, and with work is little, and especially in the art of the hand. 
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We, however, already said about that at the beginning of this book. 
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since he who is not knowing what we said about anatomy, is not purged, but rather falls into error by which men are killed: just as I saw many of those who are formed from this science and boast themselves about it without knowledge, and without experiment. 
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	This happened because I saw a stupid doctor cut open a scrofulous abscess on a woman's neck and he cut some arteries in her neck: therefore the woman's blood flowed until she fell dead between his hands. 
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another doctor who presumed to extract a stone from a man who had advanced in age and the stone was large. 
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	He therefore reached him and extracted it with a piece of bladder. 
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Therefore the man died on the third day. 
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I myself had already been called to extract it and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the sick man that he would die.  
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another doctor who was receiving a fee from a Duke of our land for medicine and it happened that a black eunuch who was with him suffered a fracture in his leg near his heel and the doctor rushed with his ignorance and bound the fracture over the wound with bandages and strong bindings and did not allow the wound to breathe. 
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he released him according to his wishes. 
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterward he dismissed him after several days and ordered him not to loosen the bandage and it remained so until his leg and foot became abscessed and it came to destruction. 
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was therefore called to him and I hurried to loosen the bandage and tranquility followed and he was freed from his pains. 
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the corruption had already been confirmed in the limb and I could not restrain it.  
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore the corruption ceased to spread in the limb until it died. 
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another doctor who pierced a cancerous abscess and it became ulcerated afterward until its malice was magnified with its master. 
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	This is because when cancer is pure from melancholic humor then it should not be reached with iron at all unless it is in a limb that can tolerate it so that its whole mass can be cut off. 
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for that reason, O sons, it is necessary for you to know that an operation with the hand is divided into two divisions: namely, operation which is associated with safety; and operation, with which there is danger in many dispositions. 
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already aroused in every place of this book, in which comes an operation, in which there is terror and fear. 
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of that, and to diminish it so that fools do not find a way to speak and dishonor. 
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore receive measure with solicitude and protection, and your sick with ease and firmness, and use the better way leading by the grace of God to salvation and praiseworthy succession: and dismiss terrible illnesses of difficult healing: and lift up your souls from that which makes you fear so that hesitation may enter upon you in your faith and well-being. 
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more lasting for your glory, and more sublime in this world, and finally to your quantities.  
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen has already said in some of his admonishments. 
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat a bad illness, lest you be named among bad doctors.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	Now this Treatise has been divided according to three Chapters.  
Capitulum primum.	Chapter One. 
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	On cautery with fire and cautery with sharp medicine, chaptered and ordered from head to foot, and forms of instruments and tools for cautery; and everything that is necessary in the operation.  
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Two. 
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On incision and perforation, phlebotomy and venesection, and wounds; and the extraction of arrows, and things similar to it; and all chaptered, ordered according to forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Three. 
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration and dislocation, and the treatment of torsion, and things similar to it; chaptered, ordered from head to foot, and according to forms of instruments. 
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory to God alone. 
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Surgical Book of Albucasis. 
Pars I.	Part I. 
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Concerning the burning and injury of cautery; and to what temperaments it is suitable; and at what time; and whether with iron or gold. 
Caput I.	Chapter I.  
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before I recall the operations performed with it, it is necessary to say what are its qualities of cauteries and their harms; and in what complexion they should be exhibited. 
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore that speech concerning the quality of cautery's benefit and its harm is a lengthy and subtle science, and a hidden secret. 
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Indeed, many wise men have spoken on this subject and disagreed; and it suffices for me a little from their speeches, fearing prolixity. 
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	Therefore I say that cautery generally confers benefit to every complexion which has matter and lacks matter, except for two complexions: a hot complexion without matter, and a dry complexion without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, in the hot and dry complexion with matter they disagreed. 
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	For some said that cautery is beneficial in it.  
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	Others said the opposite of that, namely that cautery is not suitable in a disease which arises from heat and dryness; because the nature of fire is heat; and it is inconvenient for something hot and dry to heal a disease that is hot and dry. 
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who said the opposite of that said that cautery brings benefit to every hot and dry disease which occurs in the bodies of men; because when you compare the body of man and its humors to the complexion of fire, you find the body of man cold. 
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I indeed say through his speech because experience has now revealed that to me many times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, it is not necessary for one to come upon this unless he has already been proven and practiced in the ultimate exercise of cautery and has recognized the diversity of human complexions and the disposition of diseases within themselves and their causes and accidents, and the space of time of these things. 
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	But there is no fear for you from the other temperaments; and especially in cold and humid illnesses. 
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all physicians have now agreed upon them, and they did not disagree on healing them with cautery. 
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, sons, that from the secret of healing by cautery with fire, and its goodness over cautery with burning medicine, is because fire is simple, whose action does not reach except to the member which you are cauterizing, and it does not harm another joined member with it, except for slight harm. 
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	But the action of burning medicine reaches that which is extended from the members and perhaps causes a difficulty in healing to occur in the member, and perhaps it kills it. 
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	But fire, on account of its subtlety and goodness of its substance, does not do that unless it overflows.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Indeed it has now become clear to us through experiment, because of the length of service and study with the art, and our standing upon the truth of things; and on account of that I excuse myself from the length of speech. 
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not allowed to this book of mine, I would bring to you the secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in bodies by its expulsion, by which it expels illnesses with philosophical speech demonstrative, which would be fitting for your minds. 
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, sons, that they themselves disagree on the time in which it is fitting to perform cautery, and they put forward a better time for truth.  
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cautery is fitting in all time because the harm which happens because of time is submerged in the healing which is attracted with cautery.  
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if the cautery is for pains from necessary pains, strong ones, urgent ones, which do not tolerate delay; because it is feared from them that a greater evil may happen than a slight harm entering because of time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let it not enter your minds, O sons, that which the common and foolish physicians do not believe, namely that for that illness which is healed by cautery, there is not always a return; and they put this as a consequence, but the matter is not as they think; because cautery is nothing but a medicine in its place, which alters the complexion and dries up the humors which are the causes why pains occur. 
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, cautery surpasses medicine in the speed of its healing, and the power of its operation, and the intensity of its dominion; and it is possible that the illness may return at some hour according to the complexion of the sick person, and the location of his illness, and its power; and what is prepared in his body from the aggregation of superfluities in it; and what comes to him in its acquisition from foods, and similar causes, unless the illness arises in which cautery is administered. 
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	An illness subtle in a limb with few superfluities and humors, such as cautery of a tooth, on account of pain and similar things to it, for it is possible that the pain will not return there.  
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this happens rarely. 
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But truly the common saying that cautery is the last resort of medicine is a right statement: not according to what they intend in it; for they believe that there is no cure which can compare with medicine nor with any other after the cautery has been performed.  
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	The matter is the opposite of that, and the intent in which cautery is said to be the last resort of medicine is not, except when we administer modes of treatment in some illnesses, and those medicines do not avail; then we administer cautery at the end of the matter, and it avails; then it falls that cautery is the last resort of medicine, not according to the intention which the common people and many foolish physicians understand. 
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that a cautery with gold is better than a cautery with iron; and they did not say this except on account of the equality of gold, and the subtlety of its substance; and they said that it does not produce pus at the site of the cautery. 
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But that is not absolutely true; for I have already proven it, and found that it does not do that in some bodies without others. 
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And a cautery with it is good, and better than with iron, as they said. 
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you ignite a cautery in fire made of gold, it is not shown to you, when ignited according to the quantity which you wish, because of the redness of the gold; and when cold quickly approaches it, and if you add fire on top of it, it melts in the fire, and turns into sheets. 
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the craftsman falls from it into occupation; and because of that, a cautery with iron is made among us faster and closer, from straightforwardness to operation. 
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I myself have now arranged this chapter on the cautery according to chapters; and I have arranged them from the head down to the feet, so that it may relieve one seeking that which he wants from it. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	Concerning the manner of cauterizing the head at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This cauterization pertains to the dominion of humidity and coldness over the brain; which are two causes of headache, and a multitude of flows of humors from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and a multitude of sleep, and toothache, and throat pain; and universally all sickness, which happens from coldness, such as paralysis, and headache, epilepsy, and apoplexy, and similar illnesses to those.  
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The manner of cauterization is that you order the sick person: to evacuate in the first place with cleansing medicine three nights, or four, according to what requires the strength of the infirm person, and his age, and his habit. 
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then order him to shave his head with a razor. 
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands on a stool, so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.  
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes. 
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever therefore your middle finger arrives, mark that place with a cautery. 
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then with an olive-wood cautery: which has this shape.  
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the spot marked with the cautery, descending in such a way that your hand constricts gradually, and you revolve it. 
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then lift your hand quickly and look at the place. 
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	And if you see that a quantity equal to the head of an alky or a quantity equal to rue has already been exposed from the bone, then lift your hand. 
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat your hand with the iron itself, or with another from it if it becomes cold: until the bones which I told you are seen. 
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and soak the cotton wool in it, and place it on the spot; and leave it for three days.  
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place cotton wool soaked in butter on top of it, and leave it on the spot until the burn is destroyed. 
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with tetrapharmakon ointment until it is healed.  
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	It has been said that the more a wound remains open, the more pus it emits: therefore it is better and more beneficial. 
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them have said that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone, and the cautery should be held until something of the thickness of a bone is charred. 
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then after that which has been charred is scraped off from the bone, then it is cared for.  
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that it is necessary with the cautery to reach the very end until it imprints a template on the bone so that the bone falls away, which is done like the shape of a kirate: or an instrument which women put in infused with a small alphabet; and they believe that vapors from the head are exhaled from this place and the wound is left open for a long time. 
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be cared for until it is consolidated. 
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But these two kinds of cautery do not seem to me to be anything other than according to the way of fear in certain men. 
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And to dismiss him, is better with his health according to me. 
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened from the solution of its natural continuity, as we have testified in other members; and especially when the head of a weak, feeble person is; and the first kind of cautery is indeed safer and better for me, and I use it; therefore operate with it safely.  
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	Concerning the way of cauterizing the head in pain of the whole head. 
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When a chronic pain occurs in the whole head and it is prolonged in a weak person, and they use leeches, poultices, head-purgatives, oils, and emplasters.  
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized with one cautery, which we have described, and those things do not bring him any relief, then consider. 
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of a weak person is strong by nature and is not feeble, and it encounters severe cold, then cauterize with another cautery under that one a little. 
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over the whole horn of its head with a cautery, so that it does not pass through the skin, and uncover from the bone a quantity, as we have described.  
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with one cautery on the back of its head, in the place which is called "vas"; and this place is where the wind is placed; elevate your hand in this, and do not uncover the bone. 
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the weak person finds because of that severe pain, and different from the pain of all other head cauteries. 
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I say this cautery in its place; and it is necessary that it be a cautery with which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of the head with a more subtle cautery, with which the middle of the head is cauterized. 
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the way of cauterizing in headache, both with burning medicine and with iron. 
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV. 
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain and swelling occur in a part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and the head is purged with purifying medicines, and the remaining treatment, which I mentioned in the divisions of diseases, is administered, and it does not fully resolve; then cauterization is appropriate in this case according to two methods: either cauterization with a sharp, burning medicine; or with iron. 
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	Cauterization with a sharp, burning medicine is done as follows: take one clove of garlic and peel it, and cut off its ends from both sides. 
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then split the place of pain at a time when bloodletting is broad, until a place under the skin is made where the tooth is taken. 
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Therefore insert it just under the skin until it is concealed; then bind it above with a constriction appropriate for a poultice, and leave it for fifteen hours; then loosen it and remove the garlic; and let it rest for two or three days; afterwards apply a swab dipped in butter over it until the place forms pus; then treat it with ointment until it is healed. 
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do so with certain burning medicines, which I wrote in the twelfth treatise, On Burning Medicines. 
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Cauterization of it with iron is done as follows.  
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Heat the cautery, whose shape is this. 
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called a cautery iron because the shape of its head is like the shape of a key, which has some curvature and in the middle of it there is a small prominence. 
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it upon the location and hold your hand steady; and turn the iron gradually with speed; and the amount that is cauterized should be half of the thickness of the skin. 
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And raise your hand so that the artery which is below is not injured and bleeding may occur. 
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak a compress in salt water and place it on the spot and leave it for three days; then place the compress with butter; afterwards treat with ointment until it is healed. 
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this hemi cranium with the second point of the cautery. 
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And beware of cutting an artery in this hemi cranium, not an old one properly. 
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	Concerning the method of cauterizing an old hemi cranium.
Caput V.	Chapter Five. 
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you treat a hemi cranium with what we said from the previous treatment and what we said in the divisions of diseases and the treatment does not work; and you see from the illness that it is not sufficient for it what we said from the first cautery with medicine, or with cautery with fire, then it is necessary that you ignite the knife cautery until it becomes white after you mark a line on the spot of pain whose length is half a finger, or so; and place your hand with one finger, and press it until you strike the artery and reach up to the mouth. 
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However it is necessary for you to be careful of the continuation of the mandible, which moves during chewing, lest its side or the nerve that moves it be injured, from which a spasm may occur. 
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be watchful and careful about the flow of blood from the artery which has been cut. 
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in its cutting off there is fear, and especially for him who does not know that which he is doing, and is neither studious nor experienced; and he abandons the operation with it at first. 
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will come with a recollection of the regimen of the flow of blood occurring from an artery according to its manner, and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see from the illness that this cautery is not sufficient for it, and you see the body of the weak person enduring the cautery in the middle of the head, as we have described, care for the wound until it heals. 
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, apply the cautery that we mentioned in the chapter on the extraction of an artery with a cautery having two knives. 
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cauterization is better and more effective. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the manner of cauterizing for ear pain. 
Caput VI.	Chapter Six.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear from cold and is treated with solutions and the remaining treatment as we have mentioned in the division, and the pain is not removed, then apply a cautery by fire. And this is what is called a Point, its shape is as follows.  
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then points with it after its ignition are made in a circle around the entire ear, as it revolves; or in a circle around both, if there is pain in both at the same time. 
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And distance yourself with the cautery from the root of the ear a little, after you have marked the places with an ointment; and let the quantity of the cautery be ten punctures in each ear, and like that. 
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then care for the places until they heal. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	On the manner of cauterizing for a sprain.
Caput VII.	Chapter Seven.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	A sprain that is treated with cautery is only of the types that occur from phlegm, according to what we have said in the divisions of illnesses.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And avoid cautery for types that occur from dryness and nerve spasm. 
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this type of sprain with herbs, poultices, and gargles, and your treatment does not take effect, then it is necessary that you cauterize the patient with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, the second a little below its temple, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery opposite the weak part. 
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not happen unless in the part which appears healthy. 
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is, to cauterize it with the cautery itself in a straight line from the upper extremity of the ear below the horn of the head a little; and at another time: whose length is according to the length of the thumb. 
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cautery until a quantity of half the thickness of the skin is burned. 
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a kind from the one with a blade, whose form was mentioned before; however it is not thinner by a little, as you see; and it should be that the knife in it has unnecessary thickness a little.  
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the places, with what preceded, until they are healed. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On the manner of cauterizing in old apoplexy.  
Caput VIII.	Chapter Eight. 
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy becomes old, and you care for it with what we said, and your medication does not help, and the weak person does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries above all the horn of his head, and with a cautery in the middle of the head, as we said, and with a cautery on the back of the head, according to what preceded; and let the manner of the cautery be according to what preceded.  
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Also cauterize with a cautery above the mouth of the stomach: and it is more final. 
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for it, with what preceded. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the manner of cauterizing in Oblivion. 
Caput IX.	Chapter Nine.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that first the weak person be given a large quantity of hyssop and pills that purify the brain. 
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the head of the weak person completely and place on the back of his head a plaster of sycamore as described in the treatise on plasters; and apply it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	Indeed, this is the method of cautery; and do that in the same order as I said there. 
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	Therefore if it heals thereby, it is good. 
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not, then do three cauteries on the back of his head, which descend from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye; and put the breadth of a finger between each cautery. 
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the cautery, as with the one that preceded it.  
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	But if you wish an addition, and he is able to tolerate it; then do a cautery for him in the middle. 
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	And if you wish an addition, then cauterize him above the two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then care for him until he is healed; and let the cautery be olive-shaped according to the form that was mentioned previously.  
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in paralysis and softening. 
Caput X.	Chapter Ten. 
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed with the purification of the head with hyssop and with what we have said.  
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the head of the sick person; afterwards cauterize him with a cautery in the middle of the head, and with a cautery above each horn of the head, and with a cautery above the back of it, and with three above the vertebrae of the neck. 
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	But if you are dealing with illness in softening of the body with more than those, and he is able to tolerate it, and the illness is strong; then cautery him with four cauteries above the vertebrae of the back, and the last one with a cautery until most of it is burned from the skin, and raise your hand. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for him until he is healed; and thus let the cautery be olive-shaped.  
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	Concerning the method of cauterying in epilepsy. 
Caput XI.	Chapter Eleven.  
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic is not cauterized unless his epilepsy is from phlegm. 
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore it is necessary that you cleanse his brain first of all with vinegar, and with the remaining treatment which we mentioned in the division: when he is strong, or when he can bear taking medicines. 
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	But if he is a child who cannot bear medicines, then a gargle and cleaning mastications for the brain are given before it, for many days with good food. 
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head, and afterwards cauterize it with one cautery in the middle of the head, according to what preceded in the manner; and with another cautery on the back of his head, and with a cautery over all the horn of his head. 
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	But if the sick person is strong and can bear it, then cauterize him with the cauteries which I mentioned in the one having paralysis, and softening of the body over the vertebrae of the neck and the vertebrae of the back; and let the cautery be olive-oil according to the manner which preceded. 
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if the sick person is a child then put a delicate cautery according to this manner.  
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	Concerning the Manner of Cauterizing in Melancholy. 
Caput XII.	Chapter Twelve.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the causes of melancholy are corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with the cauteries which we mentioned in the one having paralysis.  
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is a superfluity tending towards melancholy and the body of the sick person is damp, then give him a drink which will cleanse his brain, according to what preceded in the division; then shave the head of the sick person, and afterwards make a well-shaped turband out of linen, like a circle. 
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of his head; and the sick person sitting straight should be held on all sides.  
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present a liniment. 
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more fitting to be made from old butter. 
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it over a fire with a tempered heat, which the finger can bear when introduced into it.  
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle, and let it alone until it becomes cold. 
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do that to the weak one once a week, with the rest of his good regimen, until he is healed. 
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small punctures on it, except where you hold it with the cautery: let there be a smell.  
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cautery moistens the brain with quality. 
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then put a swab soaked in butter or chicken fat on top of it.  
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	On the manner of cauterizing descending to the eye in water. 
Caput XIII.	Chapter Thirteen.  
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the beginning of water in the eye is declared to you by the signs which I have said in the division, then begin and make the weak one drink, with that which cleanses his head.  
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep him from all moistures, and have him sit in a bath, fasting for several days. 
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then instruct him to shave his head, and cauterize it in the middle of his own head.  
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it above the two temples with two cauteries, if there is a beginning of the descent of water in both eyes at the same time; or from one side, if there is a beginning of water in one eye; and cut off with the cautery all the veins and arteries which are under the skin; and let the cautery be long in width above the temples; and beware of the flow of blood. 
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	For if you see anything from it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible; and I will come with the wisdom which is in the extraction of arteries and the cutting off of them and caution from the flow of blood. 
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized on the neck, under the two bones, with two cauteries lastly produced.  
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	On the manner of cauterizing old tears. 
Caput XIIII.	Chapter Fourteen. 
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When tears of the eyes are old, persistent, and are upon the veins and arteries which are on the outer surface of the head, it is verified that this is from cold, phlegmatic superfluities; then cauterize with the same cautery as I have described in the beginning of descending water, with a cautery in the middle of the head, and two cauteries upon two temples, and two cauteries on the neck under two bones. 
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if it does not yield with addition, then cauterize it on every side cautiously above the eye, upon the extremity of the eyebrow with a small cautery. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	Concerning the method of cauterizing for a foul smell of the nose.  
Caput XV.	Chapter Fifteen. 
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat it with that which we said in the division, and medication does not avail, then hasten and give in a draught three nights of infirmocochias; then shave its head and cauterize it with a medium cautery, with an olive-wood cautery. 
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with a small cautery, with two cauteries on the two eyebrows a little under the hairs. 
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery so as not to strike it.  
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of a small cautery. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	Concerning the method of cauterizing for relaxation of the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter Sixteen. 
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye becomes relaxed from illness or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, with a moon-shaped cautery. 
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows a little with two cauteries on every side; and let them be extended from the two temples; and let the length of the whole cautery be according to the lengths of the eyebrow; and do not finish your hand with the cautery, but rather according to the amount that the third eyelid is burned. 
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the shape of the cautery according to this method of lunar cautery. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	On the way of cauterizing an eyelid when prickly hairs are turned inwards and irritate the eye. 
Caput XVII.	Chapter Seventeen. 
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	A cautery is of two types: either a cautery with fire or a cautery with a burning medicine. 
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	However, in a fire cautery, advise the patient beforehand to let their hairs grow out, if they are among those who remove them, until they are lengthened and even. 
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	But if they sting him at their root, then bind his eyes with a strip so that they do not move until they are born. 
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	Therefore, when they are born and even, then place the patient's head in your lap; then mark on the eyelid of his eyes with wax, a mark that is according to the shape of a myrtle leaf; and let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.  
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place cotton soaked in albumin or in psyllium mucilage over the eye. 
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then with fire a cautery, whose shape is this.  
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the shape which you have marked gradually in many times until the surface of the skin which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf, is entirely burned properly. 
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the success of your work is: that if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracting and the hairs rising at the puncture of the eye. 
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Therefore, raise your hand then, and let him go for three days. 
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place cotton with butter on it until the eschar is eradicated.  
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with ointment until he is healed. 
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	And if any hair returns after an hour and the eyelid softens, then repeat the cautery over that place as you did at first.  
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If, however, the hairs are on the lower eyelid, then cauterize it until it is raised to its natural place; and make it even so that the hairs do not prick the eye. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	On the method of cauterizing with a burning medicine in the same case. 
Caput XVIII.	Chapter Eighteen. 
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is as if you should direct the sick person to let the hairs grow out until they are lengthened and even. 
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from paper or cloth a shape of a myrtle leaf. 
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from known soap and from lime not imbibed from each one weight of one ounce or nearly that; then grind them together with good attrition and make it quickly so that it does not become cold.  
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then from the pan spread it upon the paper which you have made like a myrtle leaf shape and place it upon the eyelid of one or both eyes. 
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a piece of cloth soaked in albuminous fluid; and let the head of the sick person be in your lap.  
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your index finger upon the medicine and press it for a short time. 
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you will move it whenever the sick person feels the bite of the medicine; because it finds its bite like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore he perseveres in this, that he finds the bite, then let go of the medicine and move it with your finger. 
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When therefore the bite quiets, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.  
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then if you see the eyelid being raised as it is raised with fire or incision, it is well; and if not, then repeat upon it from the medicine upon the place where the medicine does not imprint and does not stain until your operation is equal and the eye contracts. 
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place upon it a cloth with butter until the skin burn is eradicated. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with diaphinicon ointment or another until it heals. 
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you during surgery, that you guard with the utmost care, lest anything from the medicine should fall into the eye. 
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelid softens after a few days and something from the hairs fights its way into the eye, then repeat the medicine upon that place which softens from the eyelid itself, just as you did at first. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals. 
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of a myrtle leaf.  
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that the eyes of men are diversified in size and equality. 
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore let your consideration be according to that, and the way of righteousness is not hidden from him who has a desire concerning this art. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in lacrimal fistula.  
Caput XIX.	Chapter Nineteen. 
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you heal a fistula, as we said in the divisions of diseases, and your treatment does not work: then it is necessary that you cauterize it according to this method. 
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the sick person to put his head in your lap, and let a servant hold his head between his hands in such a way that it does not move or shake with his head. 
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then put a cotton swab soaked in egg white or in psyllium mucilage over his eye; then with fire a cautery, whose form is this. 
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be concave, like the shape of a vulture’s quill pen from one end, with which the cautery is made; and if you wish for it to penetrate all the way to the other end, and if you wish for it to go upward, then try thus. 
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However this concave shape is better for your purpose.  
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then press out the fistula if it is open and extract the pus from it and dry it out; and if it is not open, then open it and extract its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place the cautery upon it, which has been heated intensely. 
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand with it a little while by the cautery from the eye, to the side of the nose, so that your hand does not stray, or the weak one is not disturbed: and you place the cautery in the fat of the eye, and corrupt it. 
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	So if you reach in the beginning of your cautery up to the mouth, it will be well. 
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the cautery once, or twice, if it is necessary with it: and dismiss it for three days. 
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place cotton with butter, and care for it with a drying ointment until it is healed.  
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	And if forty days pass it and it does not heal: then place upon it a sharp corrosive medicine until the mouth is uncovered: and scrape it according to what comes in its chapter.  
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cautery for fistula, which some first said. 
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Attend to the place of the fistula, and find it: then put a thin camahan into the fissure, that is, a thin cannula, whose shape is this. 
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it a quantity of a drachma from melted lead, and hold your hand with the cannula in good retention, and do not move the weak one at all so that the melted lead does not run or reach its eye. 
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary that you place cotton infused in albumin, yes, or in water upon the eye of the weak one.  
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead burns the place of the fistula, and heals it with a marvelous healing. 
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed with what we said from cautery and care, it is good.  
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer a nostril, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what will come in its own place.  
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in fissures of the lips. 
Caput XX.	Chapter 20. 
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Very often there occur in the lip fissures which are called harelips, and especially in the lips of infants. 
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	Therefore when you treat these fissures, as we said in the division of diseases, and the treatment does not help, then a small heated knife cautery, according to this form. 
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its concavity be according to the subtlety of the knife.  
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the heated cautery quickly in the fissures themselves until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with cerate until it heals.  
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the manner of cauterizing a fistula of the mouth. 
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs in the root of the gum, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it makes pus and bursts: afterwards it becomes chronic and discharges pus and a fistula forms: then you treat it and the treatment does not help, then it is necessary to apply a heated cautery according to the size which will fit into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the heated iron into the opening of the fistula and hold your hand until the heated iron reaches its depth and end: do this once or twice.  
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it afterwards with what we said about care until it is healed. 
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the discharge is cut off and it heals, it will be good.  
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place and remove the corrupt bone according to what will come in its chapter. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On the manner of cauterizing the gums and softened teeth.  
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22. 
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum softens because of moisture and the teeth are loosened and you treat it with medication and it does not help: then place the head of the weak person in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then a cautery by fire, whose form will come after this, so that you put the Cannula over the tooth; and insert into it the ignited Cautery quickly: and hold your hand for a short time, until the weak one feels the heat of the fire has now reached the root of the tooth. 
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	Then raise your hand; then repeat the Cautery several times, according as you wish. 
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the weak one fill his mouth with salt water, and hold it for one hour; and spit it out. 
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth moved is made firm, and the softened gum is tightened, and the corrupted moisture is dried.  
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	Concerning the way of cauterizing in Toothache. 
Caput XXIII.	Chapter Twenty-Three.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the pain of a tooth is because of coldness, or there is cold itself in it, or a worm, and treatment with medicines does not help; then the Cautery is upon it according to two ways: either Cautery with butter; or cautery with fire. 
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	But the Cautery of it with butter is, so that you take vaccinated butter, and boil it in an iron spoon, or in a crucible. 
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take cotton, and wrap it over the end of the tentacle. 
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then dip it into the boiling butter; and put it on the painful tooth quickly, and hold it until it cools; then repeat it several times, until the power of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, dip wool, or cotton in cold butter, and put it on the aching tooth; and put ignited iron on top of it, until the fire reaches the depth of the cavity of the tooth. 
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	But cautery with fire is, so that you apply to a cannula of air, or a cannula of iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be something of thickness in its body, so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the mouth of the weak one. 
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then apply a cautery iron, the shape of which will be shown; and place it upon that tooth; and hold your hand there until the cautery iron cools. 
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Repeat this several times, for the pain will be removed, either on the same day or another day. 
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary that after the impression of the cautery iron, the sick person should fill his mouth with good butter and hold it for one hour; then spit it out. 
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the shape of the cautery iron. 
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whichever extremity you wish, as is possible; and this is the shape of the cannula.  
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterizing fistulas. 
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIV.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When fistulas are from phlegm and cold humors, and are not obedient to digestion by medicines, and you wish to hasten their digestion; then apply a concave cautery iron, the shape of which is this. 
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities so that the smoke may escape from the cautery iron at one extremity; and place it ignited upon the abscess once, and a second time if needed, until it reaches the depth of the abscess. 
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	But if the abscess is small, then place the cautery iron according to the size of the abscess. 
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then leave it for three days, and place a poultice soaked in butter upon it until what was burned by the fire is removed. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with tooth ointment until the shape of the cannula is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterizing hoarseness of voice and constriction of breathing. 
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When humors overcome the bronchial tubes, and especially when this is accompanied by coldness of complexion, then it is necessary that the sick person first be evacuated with dissolving medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it at night near the root of the throat in a depressed place, and beware that you do not reach the throat with the cautery, nor the skin except for a little bit of it.
