Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However, it must be done after evacuation with bloodletting. 
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	On the method of cauterizing arterial bleeding in a wound. 
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII. 
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Very often it happens that blood flows from an artery which has been cut at a wound, which occurs externally, or at the incision of an abscess, or a cautery of a limb, and similar things: and it is difficult to stop it. 
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	Therefore, when this happens to someone, then hurry with your hand to the opening of the artery, and place your index finger upon it: and press it hard until the blood is blocked under your finger, and nothing comes out from it. 
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then place a small olive-wood cautery in the fire and many more of a large number: and blow upon them until they become very hot.  
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one from them, either small or large, according to the wound and the place where the artery has been ruptured, and apply the cautery upon it, after which you quickly remove your finger: and hold the cautery until the bleeding is stopped. 
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	And if it is expelled when you raise your finger from the opening of the artery, and you extinguish the cautery, then quickly take another cautery from those which are prepared in the fire. 
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore, do not cease to do that with one after another until the bleeding is stopped.  
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And be careful not to burn the nerve which is there, and cause other harm to befall the weak patient. 
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, then it is not possible to stop it: especially when the artery is large, except with one of four methods. 
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we have said.  
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction when it has not been extracted. 
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its extremities are contracted and the bleeding is stopped.  
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it should be tied with a strong ligature. 
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or let medications of a kind that stanch blood be placed upon it, and let it be compressed with a decent ligature. 
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	But he who performs its excision with a ligature, and constriction with cloth, or the application of burning agents, and similar things, does not thoroughly heal it except rarely. 
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if it should happen to someone and there is neither a physician present nor medicine: then let him begin by placing the index finger upon the orifice of the vein itself, as we have described, and constrict it tightly until the blood is obstructed from the upper part of the wound and above the artery.  
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And let the finger not be removed, but constantly apply cold water of intense coldness over it until the blood congeals and thickens, and is cut off. 
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile, let him consider what he needs from cautery or medicine.  
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of the First Part. 
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	The Second Part of the Surgical Book by Albucasis. 
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Incision, Perforation, and Phlebotomy in Wounds and Similar Things. 
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already said in the First Chapter that every ailment in which it is fitting to use fire for cautery and burning medicine, its occasions, its causes, its instruments, and the forms of cauteries. 
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I have placed there chapters from head to foot.  
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter the same way, so that it may relieve the inquirer seeking his question. 
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, it is necessary for you to know, O son, that in this chapter there is terror from what is in the First Chapter on cauterization. 
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And on account of that it is necessary that there be more intense caution in it, because in the operation which is in this chapter, evacuation often occurs with blood, with which life stands at the opening of a vein, or incision over an abscess, or opening of an exit wound, or treatment of a wound, or extraction of an arrow, or incision over a stone, and things similar to these: from all of which association trembling and fear arise, and death falls upon many of them. 
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, lest it fall upon you in which there is hesitation, for sometimes there fall upon you in this art ways of men with ways of infirmities. 
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For among them is he who becomes angry with his illness, and death is light to him because of the violence he finds from his infirmity and the length of his malice.  
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with illness there is fear which signifies death. 
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And among them is he who gives you his lute player and enriches you with him, hoping for healing, and his illness is pernicious. 
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore it is not fitting that you consent to him who comes to you from among them, whose manner is such.  
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be stronger than your desire and your greed. 
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume anything from him unless after certain knowledge which verifies with you that which has come to a laudable outcome. 
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use in the care of all your sick, prognosis and indication concerning it so that health may suitably come about. 
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in that there is help for you in acquiring fame and glory, and memory and praise.  
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire in you his understanding, and not take away from you direction and inspiration for it is in his hand.  
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I indeed arranged this chapter distinguishing it by chapters, according to what preceded in the chapter on Caustic, from the neck down to the feet so that what you desire and need from it may be relieved for you. 
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	On the treatment of water which collects in the heads of infants.  
Caput I.	Chapter I.  
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this infirmity often happens to boys at birth: or when the midwife tightens the head of the boy without ease. 
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it happens also from a hidden cause which is not known.  
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I myself have not seen this illness in anyone but children, and death hastened to all of them whom I saw: therefore it seemed best to me to forgo operating on it. 
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I myself saw a boy from them whose head was filled with water, and his head swelled every day until he could not sit upon himself because of the size of his head: and the moisture increased until he died. 
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture indeed either gathers between the skin and bone or gathers beneath the bone upon the suture. 
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation on that, if the moisture is between the skin and bone, and it is a small abscess, then it is necessary that you make a single fissure in the middle of the head one finger wide: and let the length of the fissure be about two knuckles, until the moisture runs out. 
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the form of a spatula. 
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the moisture is greater and the abscess is larger, then make those two fissures according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is beneath the bone, and its sign is that you see the sutures of the head open from every side: and water is depressed when you press it with your hand towards the interior, and it does not hide from you: then it is necessary that you make three fissures in the middle of the head according to this manner. 
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision extract all the moisture. 
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then bind the fissures with cloths and lint. 
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then embrocate it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day. 
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the bandage, and heal the wound with tents and ointments. 
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not cease to bind the head evenly.  
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the sick person with all dry food of little moisture until the limb is strengthened and healed. 
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is to consider where the magnitude of the abscess appears and the collection of water. 
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes there is more in the back of the head, or in the forehead, or on the right, or on the left. 
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore ascend with an incision where you see the abscess and filling of water; and split it according to what is possible for you. 
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe that you do not cut into an artery and that a flow of blood occurs, and the sick person dies from that flow with the evacuation of moisture. 
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Concerning the incision of arteries which are behind the ears. 
Caput II.	Chapter II. 
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When it happens to someone that there are catarrs to the eyes, or to the chest, and it becomes old, and treatment with medicine does not help; then the final treatment in that case is the incision of these two arteries. 
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore it is necessary that when you wish to cut into them, that the sick person should shave their head.  
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the place with a rough cloth so that the arteries appear. 
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then let the sick person tighten their neck with any cloth of theirs.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the vein pulses. 
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the locations of both are places which are behind the ears depressed: and it is rarely hidden, except in certain people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with hot wax over each one; and cut both with a scalpel on both sides, the incision reaching the mouth; and let it be done across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert the scalpel under the artery, and cut it upwards with an incision. 
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be like two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when a vein is cut, blood comes out with a throbbing flow which leaps to the insides by frequent jumps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear to the senses, then it is necessary that you measure from the ear a distance of three fingerbreadths. 
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with hot wax and cut upwards to the mouth. 
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which must be emitted from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps you will emit more, or less from it. 
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All of that according to the quantity which appears to you from the strength of the weak person and the repletion of their artery.  
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound. 
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if anything remains at the mouth of the wound from the incision, then cut that out so that a hot abscess may not occur; then bind the wound with lint from linen cloth.  
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals. 
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	Concerning the extraction of arteries which are in the temples.  
Caput III.	Chapter III. 
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man that an old hemicrania, or acute catarrh occurs because of acrimonious humors, and heat in the fleshy parts of the temples, or an old, vehement soda, and similar things to those; and he is treated with methods of medical treatment, and it does not help: then we have experienced in these illnesses the extraction of arteries from the temples, or their cauterization, as we have described. 
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of procedure in their extraction is that the weak person shaves the hairs which are in the temples, and stretches towards the apparent artery in the temple.  
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For it itself shows itself to you from its pulse, and rarely is it concealed except in a few men, or extreme cold.  
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	But if it is concealed from you, then let the weak person bind their head with any cloth; then rub the place with a rough cloth. 
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or steam the place with hot water until it appears to you with manifest appearance.  
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the speculum, which I had previously prepared. 
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape away the skin with it easily, until you reach the artery.  
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then project a hook into it and draw it upwards until you draw it out from the skin, and make it come out from all the tunics which are under it. 
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If, however, the artery is slender, then envelop it with the extremity of a hook. 
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then make an incision into it according to the amount by which its extremities will be extended and contracted so that a flow of blood does not occur. 
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not incised and not cut off, the blood does not rise completely. 
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then evacuate from six ounces of blood up to three. 
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if the artery is large, it is necessary that you tie it in two places with a doubled, strong silk thread or with silkworm gut so that decay does not hasten to it before the wound consolidates and a flow of blood occurs. 
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then make an incision into the excess which is between the two ligatures.  
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this in that hour or after another hour. 
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the bone with a knife cautery until its extremities fall away and it remains in place of the same operation. 
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And this is a better procedure unless the patient has a fever or an overheated complexion.  
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Because a cautery is one of those things that help to finish humidities. 
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is a better remedy.  
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of arteries that the place be filled with old cotton and poultices be placed on top, loosely made. 
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after it is dissolved, it should be treated with dry medicines that cause flesh to grow and with dressings until it heals.  
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if meanwhile while you are operating a flow of blood occurs from the artery, then hurry to cut it off with a cautery or to fill the place with wax and bind your hand until the bleeding is stopped.  
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	But if none of these things are present to you, then place your finger on top of the place until the blood clots. 
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	Embrocate the place with water of sharp cold until the sharpness is stilled, and bind it as needed. 
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And because that which is lighter and easier to extract is the vein, it is so that you should cauterize the vein with this cautery having two knives; and let the sharpness of the two knives be similar to a razor. 
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However they are of much less sharpness than two knives. 
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are sharp like two knives, cold will quickly occur to both; and they will not strike the flesh with speed. 
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Therefore since there is a little thickness in them, the heat of the fire is retained in them and the flesh is cut quickly; with this therefore it is better, lighter, and easier work.  
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space which is between the two knives be the thickness of a finger, after you have marked two places with a cautery; and lay both ignited strongly until they reach the mouth, and fall upon the vein in two places: so that what is between its ends may be lengthened. 
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they are not entirely consolidated with this cautery.  
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery. 
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	On the treatment of a sharp, persistent flow of tears from the eyes.  
Caput IIII.	Chapter Four. 
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When the tears are persistent, and their flow is from the veins which are above the outer skull; and no medicinal treatment confers anything with medicines, and you see the face of the sick person already reddening, and he feels a movement on his forehead like that of ants walking; and his eyes are weakened, moist, so that his eyelashes have already been corroded: and his eyelids are heated from the sharpness of the tears; then the ancients used to employ this operation in their treatment, and they called it treatment with the sword.  
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is so that you order the sick person to shave the hairs which are on his forehead. 
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions in the forehead equidistant according to the length of the forehead; and let the length of an incision be like two fingers, and one incision be equidistant from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second a little behind the length of the motion of the masticatory muscles, and the third on the other side. 
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce a speculum with two pointed ends, which soon follows this form. 
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is from the side of the temple up to the second incision; and with it all the skin which is between the two incisions, together with the sifac, which is above the mouth. 
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then also do that from the middle incision up to the second incision.  
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract this speculum and introduce into the first incision again another instrument which is called a sharp curette, blunt on one side, not sharp on the other side.  
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form. 
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side against the flesh joined with skin, and its blunt side towards the mouth; and press it until it reaches the middle fissure; and cut off with it all the vessels which descend from the head to the eyes: except that the incision continues until it appears from the skin. 
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do that in the middle fissure up to the other fissure.  
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after an equal quantity flows out from the blood, press out the places from lumps of clotted blood. 
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place in all the fissures a lint made from old linen and put over them compresses soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar. 
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that a hot abscess does not occur.   
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day loosen the ligature and administer a plentiful infusion with warm water. 
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with royal ointment and other remedies that heal wounds until it is healed. 
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	On the treatment of acute tearings and discharges to the eyes from within the head.  
Caput V.	Chapter Five. 
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When someone has acute, sharp, and persistent discharges, and you see their eyes are weakened, small, and their gaze has already become feeble; and the eyelids are ulcerated, and hair falls out from them, and there is a sharp, piercing pain deep in the head, and consequent sneezing: then take from these occurrences that those humors and discharges do not come except from many veins. 
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the better cure for them is this.  
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, that you order the sick person to shave their forehead. 
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make one fissure in the middle of the forehead, or a little to one side, by its width, and begin with the fissure from the left temple to the right temple; and let the incision be up to the mouth; and extend your hand away from the temporal muscles which move at mastication: until when the mouth is exposed; and you will dry up all the blood with a sponge.  
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the fissure with old cotton or linen cloths. 
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind over it with lint; and saturate the lint with wine and oil so that a hot abscess does not occur. 
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you loosen that, and you see that the hot abscess has already subsided; then it is necessary that you freeze the mouth until flesh begins to grow in it.  
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then care for it with a drying regimen that causes the flesh to grow; such as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony; and prepare an adhesive plaster from them, and apply it to the birth of flesh in these wounds. 
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	On the treatment of what falls into the Ear.  
Caput VI.	Chapter VI. 
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the ear is of one of four kinds: either a mineral stone or something like a stone, such as iron and glass; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is a flowing substance, such as water and vinegar, and things similar to them; or some animal. 
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	Therefore, when a stone or something like a stone falls into the ear that neither adheres nor grows in the ear, expose the ear to the sun: then if you see the stone, distill something from oil of violets or sesame into the ear. 
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then perform its extraction, and make him sneeze with something sugared, and press his nostrils at the time of the sneeze, after you have placed around the ear wicks from cloth or wool, and extended the ear upwards. 
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Very often it comes out with this care. 
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not come out, then perform its extraction with forceps, that is, thin Pizigaroli: whose form is this.  
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If, therefore, it comes out with forceps, it is good. 
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then perform its extraction with a thin blind hook of few twists. 
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If, therefore, it does not come out through that, then make a tube from bronze, and insert the end of the tube into the ear canal much, and pack what is around the tube with softened wax mixed with oil so that there is no way for air except through the tube: then extract it with your own breath with strong suction. 
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Very often it comes out by what we have described.  
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not come out this way: then take a small amount from hellebore or viscus, that is, prepared gluten with which birds are caught: and place it on the end of a probe after you have wrapped a well-positioned cotton over it: then insert it into the ear canal with ease, after you have dried the ear from moisture. 
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	Therefore if it does not exit with all that we have described, then hurry to incise it before a hot abscess or spasm occurs. 
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the method of incision is that phlebotomists make it first on the cephalic vein and extract from it blood according to his strength. 
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the infirm person sit between your hands and turn his ear upward, and make a small incision at the root of the ear near its fat in a depressed place; and let the incision be moon-shaped until you reach the stone; then remove it with what is possible for you from the instruments.  
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then sew up the incision quickly with care, and attend to it until it heals. 
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	But if the thing falling into the ear is a single grain that grows and swells, then administer its extraction. 
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not yield to your efforts, then take a thin, delicate spatula of this shape.  
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the cutting off of that kind of grain that falls into the ear, and do not do this when you think that the grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear, until you put many splinters on it; then extract them with hooks or with a delicate probe or with suction as we have said, for its extraction is alleviated. 
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But with regard to water that enters the ear, it is necessary for the infirm person to use sneezing when it is first instilled; and he has already filled his ear with a little old cooked oil; and he lies upon the ear in which there is water. 
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it exits through that route, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones according to the length of a finger, thin and smooth, and heat them slightly with fire; and let the infirm person insert one of them into the opening of his ear; and jump on one foot from that side, and strike it with another stone on top of the stone which is in the ear. 
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore it shall not cease to do this with stone and stone, until all the water has come out. 
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now the water comes out so that you may take one from a crucible, or from a reed, and insert one end into the ear; and set fire to the other end until most of it is burned. 
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat with another reed and do this many times until all the water has come out; and extract it with a tube as was previously described in the stone. 
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	But in the extraction of an animal entering it, if it is of a small body, such as a flea and the like, take care of it as I said in the division. 
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of large body, which appears to the senses; then administer its extraction with gestures and hooks; and its matter is easier than all that are held in the ear. 
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	But in the extraction of a generated worm in the ear, when you care for it with that which we said in the division and in the treatise on distillations, and your treatment does not succeed; then it is necessary that you look at the ear in the sun. 
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore anything from worms appears there, then extract it with gestures or with delicate hooks.  
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing appears there, then take a tube, whose form is narrow below, wide above; and insert the slender end into the ear according to the quantity that the weak one bears it: then suck with it with strong suction.  
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times until all the worms come out. 
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you to go out, then smear the circumference of the tube with wax, as I said in the stone. 
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	But if they do not come out with what we said; then administer distillations which the ancients have already experienced in the infection of worms; and you will find that in the treatise on distillations. 
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	Let your effusion with which you pour oils and medicines into the ear be with this instrument, whose form is depicted here. 
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	Make it yourself of silver or bronze, narrow below, in which there be a small hole, wide above.  
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let it therefore be such that driving what is in the cavity of the cannula is made of bronze cleanly. 
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a ray and wrap cotton about its end with decent winding; then pour oil or juice or whatever you wish from these medicines into the cannula; and let it be in the ear; then insert the ray with the cotton on top and press it with your hand with temperate compression until the oil is driven into the cavity of the hearing and the sick person feels it within; and let what is poured into the ear already be warmed a little with fire; and beware that nothing which distills into it is very cold, for medicines do not endure it. 
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	Concerning the treatment of accidental hair loss of the ear.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII. 
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes certain infants depart from the wombs of their mothers not perforated. 
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it also happens to certain men hair loss in the ear canal from a wound or flesh born therein.  
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this hair loss sometimes happens deep within the cavity of the ear which does not follow sight; and sometimes it happens near the outer opening a little and follows sight. 
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That therefore which occurs deep within the ear and which does not grasp sight is in many dispositions difficult healing.  
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which follows sight, it is necessary that you place the ear of the sick person in the sun and look into it; then if you see an apparent hair loss, open it with a delicate speculum, whose form is as follows: let its extremity in which there be a certain small width have a certain pointed part; and let the remaining speculum be of two smooth sides so that it does not injure the ear. 
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore the growth is fleshy and arises within the ear canal: then seize it with a fine hook, and cut into it with vigorous ease until all the flesh is removed. 
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	But if the growth is deep within the ear: then take a fine, smooth probe and heat it slightly with fire; then insert it into the ear canal. 
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If therefore you feel the growth with it, as the one afflicted finds with hearing impairment, try to open it with ease: and beware not to wound the nerves of the ear. 
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place in the ear a lint according to the size of the opening which you enclosed in Egyptian ointment; do this for several days until you are sure of the wound's healing. 
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take lint and steep it in rose water, and sprinkle upon it ground tragacanth, and use it. 
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	But if you see that the ear is already abscessed: then it is necessary to remove the lint and let it remain with another lint which you wrap in cerate made with rose oil until the hot abscess subsides; then care for it until it heals. 
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	But if bleeding should occur: then immerse a sponge or cloths in cold water and place them over the ear; and use the remaining treatment which stops the aforementioned bleeding as described in the treatise on distillations.  
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Concerning the care of Althea eyelids. 
Caput VIII.	Chapter Eight.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These Althelias which occur on the eyelids are sometimes moist and sometimes dry. 
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore it is necessary to hold them with tweezers or a hook and cut them from their roots with a scalpel.  
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place ground tragacanth on the spots. 
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a fine lentil-shaped cautery.  
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And to cauterize them is better after the incision. 
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For it often happens that they return when something remains from their roots. 
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and they do not return. 
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	On the treatment of Hailstones on the eyelids of the eye.  
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	It often happens that something occurs in the eyelids which resembles a Hailstone in its firmness and hardness, and on account of this it is called a Hailstone: and it is an aggregation of thick humidity in the upper eyelid and the lower eyelid. 
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation on them therefore is, that you consider then if it is a Hailstone arising in it, which appears from the eyelid and moves to every part, and its matter is easy. 
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Make therefore a fissure upon it across its width. 
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then pare it away from every part with ease until it comes out.  
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a hook and cut it off. 
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if its excision is not prepared for you except after you penetrate the eyelid with an incision a little, then it harms the weak one in some way.  
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the fissure is large: then join it with suture and care for it until it heals. 
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.  
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For ointment restores it and makes it flesh.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the Hailstone is inclined towards the inner parts of the ear towards the inner surface, then invert the eyelid and suspend the Hailstone with a hook: besides which you will need an incision and press it from every part. 
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	But if the eyelid is lengthened by the incision, it harms no one.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision of the Hailstone with salt water and care for the place with that which makes flesh until it heals the weak one. 
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the treatment of Axirnaths of the eyelids.  
Caput X.	Chapter Ten. 
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a fat which is generated in the tunics of the upper eyelid; and it most often happens to boys; and it weighs down their eyes, and catarrhs happen to them in the mornings, and they are not able to look at the light of the sun, therefore because tears hasten to them, and for that reason you see them lying down on their faces always, and sleeping upon them, and their eyelids are moist under their eyebrows, which have already been covered by swelling; and indeed the prominence of Axirnath is apparent to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them. 
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of its operation is that the sick person should put his head in your lap. 
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare on it lint, and make from that lint a circle according to the quantity which contains the Axirnath from every side. 
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then put it on top of it and press with your fingers from every side so that the Axirnath gathers in the middle of the circle. 
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that moisture with a scalpel making incisions across its width, and let there not be an incision larger than that which is made in bloodletting deep. 
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or it is necessary that you cut the entire skin until you reach the Axirnath, for in many dispositions it proceeds from the incision according to the shape of a white tallow candle.  
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Therefore extract it with the cloth which you infiltrated between your fingers to the outside; and you turn your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed; and be careful not to add to the incision so that you do not reach with the scalpel to the eye, and injure it. 
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the incision, you add a little to the incision with ease until the Axirnath proceeds.  
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it as we have said. 
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse cloths in vinegar and water, and place them over the area, and bind it with bandages. 
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are those among men who grind salt, and place it in the cavity of the fissure, so that it liquefies what remains from that moisture. 
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals. 
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if an abscess occurs in a warm place, then treat it with soothing plasters until it heals. 
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	Concerning the ways of softening the eyelid of the eye, that is, when the eyelid of the eye softens, from which it becomes swollen as it should not. 
Caput XI.	Chapter XI. 
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hairs are born on the eyelids of the eye in addition to the course under the natural hairs, and they grow long: then they harm the eye, and cause illnesses to occur, such as constant tears, and softening of the eyelids, and leukoma, until it becomes a cause for the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And indeed Ataxmir of the eye is cured according to four methods. 
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cautery with fire.  
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with a sharp medicine, according to what has been stated in the chapter on cautery. 
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or Ataxmir is cured by incision and suture.  
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or through reeds, according to what I will say. 
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary that you place the head of the sick person in your lap.  
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn back the eyelid of the eye with your left hand. 
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If therefore it is turned back, it is good.  
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: introduce a needle into it, in which there is a thread from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle with the thread penetrate from above, and let it be near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid, in which the hairs are born: and draw the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it back with a rod. 
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find on the inner part of the eyelid under the added hairs with the speculum entering from the greater lacrimal to the lesser lacrimal. 
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then extract the thread, and place under the eyelid a small pledget from linen, or cloth; then mark upon the eyelid with resin, so that it be like the shape of a myrtle leaf. 
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it is necessary that the shape be made according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid; because now it is diversified in men. 
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For among them there are some who need a large quantity to be cut from the eyelid, according to the quantity which is softened by the eyelid.  
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with the speculum find upon the two lines which you have marked, and begin from the greater lacrimal to the lesser lacrimal, and let there be one fissure near the natural hairs, such as is the thickness of a radius. 
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then introduce the hook into one of the two angles of the skin.  
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then flay the whole thing itself.  
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then unite the two lips with a suture, with a sharp needle and fine woolen thread; and cleanse away the blood, and make what runs over from the threads adhere to the two eyebrows, with certain imperceptible things, if you wish to do it; and if not, do not trouble yourself.  
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the suture and threads until three or four days; afterwards attend to it. 
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without a suture and attend to it with something that dries and constricts it.  
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is raised at the sealing of the wound and its union; but it will be better in the future. 
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of healing was taught by the ancients from Ataxmir. 
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However there is solicitude over the sick person in it and it is from a good operation, and there is no fear in it. 
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method is in Ataxmir also: and it is, that you make a sign upon the eyelid in the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we have described. 
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then raise the eyelid with three hooks separate or joined together, according to this following form, then cut off what is superfluous with small forceps, according to this form, with equal incision. 
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if it is not possible for you to hold a hook, and it does not align: then take a needle in which there is a thread, and insert it into the middle of the figure; and insert another thread near the larger lacrimal, and a second thread near the smaller lacrimal: and gather the threads between your fingers with equality.  
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand with equal elevation; and raise the skin above which the cotum is signed, as we have described. 
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the two lips of the wound with suture; and care for it until it heals.  
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if an abscess should occur at your incision or fissure: dry it up with cerate and such like, from soothing ointments. 
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens to the eyelid also, that its hairs turn.  
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore it is necessary for you to use what we have said in the incision; but the suture of both is more artful.  
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Concerning the care of Ataxmir with dogs. 
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is, that you turn the eyelid, and split the fissure which is inside, according to what I have described. 
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then with art make two reeds or two slender pieces of wood: whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and their width is less than the width of a spatula; and you have already cut into the ends of each from both sides where you hold the threads. 
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather each with subtlety above that which overflows from the eyelid of the eye, and tighten the two reeds from both sides with a strong binding, and leave it for several days. 
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For indeed the tightened skin will die and blacken and putrefy until it falls off by itself. 
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	Therefore if it is delayed, then cut it with forceps. 
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals. 
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it firms up, the eyelid is elevated: and the hairs do not sting. 
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of two tubes, which you will make according to this figure and quantity in length and width. 
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Concerning the elevation of stinging hairs in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter Twelve.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation on it is that you take a fine needle and insert into it a fine, smooth silk thread.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then you gather its ends and tie each with a fine knot: and let the length of the threads be one palm. 
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then you place another fine thread underneath it briefly in a linen cloth and tie its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then let the patient place their head in your lap and be near the sun so that the operation is illuminated: because it is a subtle or minute operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then introduce the needle with the thread into the root of the eyelid and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly until you pull out the natural hair from above. 
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw the hair up to above the thread and introduce it into the thread; if there is one, or two, or three, no more. 
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand with it until the hair comes out with the thread in the eyelid with the natural hair. 
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the thread is pulled and the hair does not come out with it, pull the thread down, with the thread which you have placed in it, until the thread comes out from the upper hole, and look at it with the eye; then pull the thread and the thread and take both out and close the eye, and leave it closed for two days or three until the hair adheres to its place and flesh grows over it.  
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	But if the hair is short, then either join to it a long hair from the natural hairs and it is raised with it, or leave it until it lengthens after a time, and then raise it. 
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	Concerning the care of an alxatrati which occurs in the upper eyelid. 
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII. 
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this alxatrati happens to the eye, it is called Leporina.  
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this alxatrati is either natural or accidental. 
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Accidental therefore comes from the consolidation of a wound, or an incision, or a cautery, and things similar to these.   
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of treatment for it is that you cut open that consolidation and separate its lips, and place in it a licorice from flax, and bind it until it heals. 
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not necessary that you use things in its treatment which dry and constrict; for if you do that, the alxatrati returns worse than it was: rather use things in it which soften, such as fenugreek: and embrocate with water in which marshmallow has been cooked, flaxseed: and an ointment of dyaquilon, which has been liquefied with some oil; and wrap it with licorice and care for it.  
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the treasure of your healing is to try with all your ingenuity that it does not become consolidated according to the form which it had at first. 
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we have said is nothing but a certain rectification of the Alxatrati so that the shape of the place does not return according to what it was at all. 
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	On the treatment of the Alxatrati which is done in the lower eyelid and it is a wrinkling or contraction upwards to the right and left. 
Caput XIIII.	Chapter Fourteen. 
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This Alxatrati which occurs below is the one that is truly called Alxatrati. 
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural and accidental. 
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental kind arises from a wound, or fissure, or cautery, and things similar to these.  
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way of operation on it is to take a needle with a double thread and dye it in flesh and make it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right tear duct until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.  
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh upwards with the needle and cut it with a broad spatula. 
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns as it should be, it is good.  
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a ray and place it in the fissure and turn it with the eyelid; and make two fissures on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two fissures be from the two angles of the incision until they come together and an angle is made from them: until when they are joined the shape of them becomes this shape, which is the Greek letter lambda. 
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount which is the sharp side below it from that which follows the eyelid.  
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separated parts; or sew them together with wool thread. 
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we have said, about softening medicines and cleansing ones until they are healed.  
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if a laceration should occur from a fissure, and by suture or cautery: then it is necessary that you split the fissure flat under the eyelashes, even according to what preceded. 
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with a ligature, according to what we have said. 
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the sum of the matter concerning the treatment of a laceration, whether it is above or below, is that the operation should proceed therein according to what is prepared from the form of the laceration. 
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it is of many different forms; and a prudent craftsman prepares his skill in whatever way is possible for him, until he restores the shape to its natural form or near it, and himself, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in very many arrangements.  
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Concerning the adhesion of the eyelid of the eye with the conjunctiva or cornea. 
Caput XV.	Chapter Fifteen.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this consolidation happens to many people, so that the upper eyelid becomes consolidated with the white of the eye and prevents it from its natural operations.  
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore it is necessary that you introduce the extremity of a radius under the eyelid and raise it upward: or extend it with a hook: then incise the adhesion with a fine spatulim which is not sharp in its incision but rather blunt; so that the infirm person will not be agitated at the operation, and the spatulim be removed and injure the eye with its sharpness: and let your incision be as if you were scraping away that adhesion with ease until when the eyelid returns to its natural form and the whole adhesion is healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye, with blue water washing it: or distill into it from a sieve made, from ziniar dissolved in water.  
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a ligature of flax: and place wool infused with egg white on top of the eye: and after the third day use a sieve and apply solid dressings until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	On the cutting of the nail and the prominence of flesh of the tear duct. 
Caput XVI.	Chapter Sixteen. 
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the nail is according to two manners. 
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Either it is nervous; and it is similar to a hard, subtle reed. 
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to frozen white humidity; which when it touches iron, or you try to take it with a hook, it is cut, and the hook does not hold fast in it.  
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin, except from the greater tear duct, until it goes gradually, until it covers the sight, and prohibits light and the movement of the eye.
