Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the manner of operation in its cutting is: that the patient should place his head in your lap.  
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes, and lift the eyelid with your hand. 
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then collect the nail with a hook of few duplications, and extend it upward.  
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle, and insert into it a hair from the hairs of a horse, an ox, or a cow; and let the thread be strong, and double the extremity of the needle a little, and fix it in the middle of the nail: and penetrate it with the needle, and tie the nail with thread, and extend it upward; and skin with the hair the side of the nail which follows the pupil, as if you press it with the hair up to its last part.  
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remainder at the root of the tear duct with a fine scalpel, or with small forceps; and let the natural flesh of the tear duct be released, so that a continuous flow of tears does not occur from its incision. 
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the nail is extended with a hook alone; or with thread, as we have said.  
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it is skinned with a gentle scalpel, of which this is the form. 
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And be careful that the scalpel does not touch the corneal tunic, and a rupture occurs in it, and the pupil is perforated. 
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, throw into the eye something crushed salt, or a powder made from alum, and leave it until another day. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of it with what is necessary until it heals. 
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	But if the nail is not nervous, and you cannot insert a point into it, nor does a hook take hold in it, then this kind of nail is often cured with medicines and heals as I described in the division. 
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	But if you wish to cut it, then open the eye of the weak person and take a subtle spatula, gentle, of weak sharpness, according to this form.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And shave off the nail from above with subtlety. 
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	But if you see that it becomes thinner and breaks, and the razor presses into it, then distill from your own hour into the eye a powder made from alum, or red ochre, or crushed salt: and bandage the eye until another day. 
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat the operation on it until the whole of it is removed.  
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless there is a hot abscess in your eye, then let it be and take care of the abscess until it heals. 
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation on it with a razor until it heals.  
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	But if the prominence of the tear duct flesh harms the eye greatly, suspend it with a hook and cut out a part of it: and do not finish the incision so that the course of the tears does not occur. 
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then distill into the tear duct red ochre or powder made from alum until it heals.  
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	On the incision of the Alguardenic and flesh born in the eye.  
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.  
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Sometimes red flesh grows in the eyes of some men, superimposed or placed on top until it covers the pupil, or approaches it, or constricts upon the eyelids, and perhaps turns the eyelids outward; and it resembles a rose balustrade.  
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation on it is also such that the sick person should place their head in your lap. 
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open their eyes and gather all that flesh with suitable hooks; and hold it with one forceps or hand. 
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh first, until all of it is finished with a scalpel.  
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And be careful from the eye so that you do not injure it during the operation; and let your incision be with which you cut it, or with a spathe, as we have described in the incision of a nail; or with small forceps with which asebel is collected, according to the shape that will come after this chapter.  
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When therefore your incision is completed and all of the albuginea is removed, then fill the eye with crushed salt; or distill into it red powder and those similar to it from corrosive medicines; and place on the eye outside cotton wool with white lead: so that it is secured from a hot abscess.  
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	But if anything remains from the albuginea, and hot blood prevails over you, and you fear a hot abscess; then leave the eye, and treat it with that which calms an abscess. 
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat upon it with the operation until it is healed.  
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And do similarly with added flesh which occurs in the eye from this kind. 
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	However it is necessary that others treat the care of all weak eyes from a natural or accidental way by operating with iron; and do not insert your hand into any of these operations until you see that that member tolerates that operation. 
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	On the Gathering of Pterygium from the Eye.  
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18. 
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Pterygium is reddish veins which are woven over the eye and prevent vision from its operation; and weaken the eye with the length of days. 
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	It is therefore necessary for you first to consider if the eye in which there is pterygium is strong and if there is no illness in it except for the pterygium; then gather its pterygium. 
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is, that you order the sick person to put his head on your lap. 
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those good things with one hook, or two according to your prudence; and let the hook be subtle, of a doubling, according to this form, or let there be two hooks graded in one body, according to this form. 
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then gather with subtle forceps those veins with subtlety, and wipe away the blood hour by hour, until you see those veins remove from the eye, and they are resolved; and beware lest you injure the eye with the extremities of the speculum. 
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your operation be in the middle of the day before the sun, and be firm in your operation very much: so that you do not fall except upon those veins. 
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then distill into the eye green vitriol, or red; so that with its sharpness it corrodes what remains from the rheum. 
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	But if it is not possible for you to gather all of it in that hour, then plaster the eye with what soothes the pain of the eye; and leave it for several days, until its pain subsides: and guard against a warm poultice; then repeat upon it according to the same manner, until it is healed.  
Et haec est forma forficis.	And this is the form of the forceps. 
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	Concerning the reduction of arrisati to the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter Nineteen.  
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Physicians call arrisati a fistula, which you cure with a cautery, or with sharp burning medicine, according to what preceded its account. 
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, then there is no skill in it except that you cleave upon the abscess at its nativity and extract all the moisture which is in it and the pus until the mouth is exposed. 
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When therefore the mouth is exposed, and you see in it corruption, or blackness, then extirpate it with an instrument, whose form is this. 
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called Asperi of the head. 
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Let it be made of tempered iron, and let its head be round like an awl, which shall be punctured with the puncture of a file, or the puncture of a fine aliskilfer; and place it upon the corrupted place of the bone. 
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then revolve it between your fingers, and press your hand upon it a little while, until you know that corruption is already planed; and do that several times. 
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with drying astringent medications.  
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	And if the place is consolidated and flesh arises in it, and the course of blood is cut off; and it remains for forty days and does not renew and does not fester and no incident occurs in it: then know that it has already been healed. 
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, there is no remedy in it except to reduce the fistula to the nostril, according to this form. 
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is to uncover the second bone with iron or with a sharp medicine; and when the bone has been uncovered, then take an auger according to this form, let its iron end be triangular: and let its wood be a pyramid thinned down to the extremity, as you see.  
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place that upon the bone itself; and let it be near the lacrimal; and extend your hand a little from the eye. 
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then revolve your hand with the auger until it penetrates the bone, and feels it weak; through this it finds wind coming out of it, when it holds its hand over its nose. 
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then restore the place with astringent drying medications as I taught you.  
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When flesh arises and the place hardens, then the matter which was flowing outwards returns to the nose; therefore it is lighter upon the weak one. 
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	On the Reduction of an Eye Prominence
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.  
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye protrudes with all its entirety, and there is neither injury nor diminution in vision; then it is necessary that you loosen what is weak; afterwards phlebotomize him; afterward place cupping glasses on the neck without scarification, but with suction. 
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Afterwards place upon the eye a liniment which is made from acacia, and aloe, and olibanum, and sarcocolla. 
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Afterwards bind the eye above with a plaster with many poultices. 
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the manner of the poultices is: that you take many soft cloths, and double every cloth from them over four; make many from them; then place them one upon another, according to the amount which the eye needs; then bind above them with a hard cloth with strong binding. 
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And repeat cupping glasses with suction without scarification. 
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the cupping glasses, and let the eye be bound day and night. 
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	But if the bandage again becomes soft, then it is necessary that it be bound tightly; then remove the bandage after a day and night, as we have said. 
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If therefore you see the eye already having returned to its tunic, it is good; and if not, then repeat the plaster, and poultices, and binding, and cupping glasses until it is healed.  
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	Concerning the incision of the tunic. 
Caput XXI.	Chapter Twenty-One.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a rupture occurs in the tunic of the eye, and then it protrudes and proceeds outside the eyelids like a grain of the eye, and the form of man is spoiled because of that, and vision enters into it: then the operation on it is as follows, according to what I narrate; and it is, that you insert a needle into the root of the eye from the lower to the upper part. 
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then insert another needle in which there is double thread from the lacrimal part, and make it penetrate; and let the first needle go according to its disposition.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the place with a double-edged knife and tie it to the part you want to take out with thread around the point of a needle: and tighten it very much. 
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then take out the needle and place on the eye wool steeped in the white of an egg: and leave it until the thread falls with the part you want to take out. 
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the eye with what strengthens it until the wound is healed. 
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And sometimes the part is compressed from every side with a circle of cloth, until the eye gains great prominence. 
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then pierce it with a fine lancet, which reaches the depth of the eye, and let the white moisture run out, and let the eye descend and enter immediately: then tighten it until it is healed. 
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	On the treatment of Alcomnatia. 
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.  
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This disease which is called Alcomnatia is nothing but a humor that gathers in the eye, like descending water and it is not itself. 
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the way to operate on it is to have the sick person sit on a prepared seat, or straight.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take his head with your hands from both sides and move it until you see the humor reach the lower parts of your eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then fix it so that it does not descend and illuminate the light: and let the sick person see things as they saw them: and if it does not descend below, you know that it is water. 
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	But if the descent of the humor is not prepared with what we have said, then make the sick person sit between your hands. 
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a fine lancet and pierce above the corneal membrane a little at the continuation of the conjunctiva with the corneal tunic, until the humor comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Therefore when it comes out, then distill into the eye warm water in which you mixed honey: or water in which you already boiled fenugreek and honey: then treat it with the rest of the treatment until it is healed. 
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	Concerning the treatment of water descending into the eye, or cataract. 
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII. 
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have already spoken of the kinds of water in division, and what is suitable for perforating by speech declaring and expounding, then take that same according to health. 
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then it is necessary that you make the weak person sit between your hands square, opposite the light, near the sun; and bind his sound eye, and constrict him strongly; then pull down the eyelid of his eye with your right hand, if the eye in which there is water, is the left eye; or with your left hand, if the eye is the right. 
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take an almond with your right hand, if the eye is the left; or with your left hand, if the eye is the right. 
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the extremity of the almond near the cornea for the thickness of a ray in the very whiteness of the eye apparent to the lachrymal minor; then press the almond with force; and you revolve with it your hand, until it penetrates into the albuginea of the eye; and feel that the almond has now reached the empty thing. 
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that the measure of the journey of the almond to the depth be the measure of the space which is from the pupil to the end of blackness; and this is the cornea of the eye.  
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	For you will see it in the very pupil by vision of the eye, because of the clarity of the tunic of the cornea. 
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the almond up to the place in which there is water. 
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press it down below with juice one after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If therefore the water descends immediately, then the weak person sees that above which he opens his sight immediately, and the almond in his eye. 
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest a little.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If therefore the water descends, then lay it aside second, beyond which the almond goes forth. 
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	Therefore when it is fixed and does not rise: then extract the almond with ease: and you turn your hand gradually. 
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve something from clear salt of gems in water: and bathe the eye inside with it.  
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place an entire cotton plug, or wool soaked in rose oil, and egg white over the eye: and bind it with the healthy eye. 
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	We however, and those who are of our time, place ground cinnamon with egg white over it. 
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	But if the almond does not obey you to enter the eye because of its hardness, since it is from a man whose eye is very hard: then it is necessary that you take an instrument, which is called Alberid, which has this shape. 
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Therefore perforate only the conjunctiva with it, and do not insert your hand into the hole: and it is only so that you make a way for the almond to a subtle place. 
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the almond, as we have said. 
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And at the completion of your work, prepare a decently made bedroom for the weak one, in which he sleeps on his back in a darkened house: and prohibit him from all movements, and coughing: and place his food that which soothes his nature: and let him not move his head to the right, nor to the left at all.  
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the bandage be according to its arrangement until the third day. 
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then loosen it in that darkened house and you will want to test his sight: and make him see things.  
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the bandage until the seventh day. 
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it is not necessary that he do this at the hour of healing, or immediately after the incision: rather it must be done by others: because water rises quickly through a strong gaze.  
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	But if a hot abscess occurs: then it is necessary to loosen the eye before the seventh day: and correct it with that which soothes the abscess until it is soothed: then restore his sight, and place an oral remedy upon his face by which his vision is regulated under it for several days, himself existing in that darkened house. 
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then let him go out of the house gradually, and walk about in his own rooms. 
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that in surgery a student is not excused from watching many times; then let him dare to operate. 
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed there has come to us a certain one of those who are from Alacrech, who said that there was made in Alacrech a well perforated, by which water is drawn up. 
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	But therefore I have not seen anyone in your land who has done that; nor have I read it in any of the ancient books; and it is possible that it is new. 
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of species from a well, so that he who does not know them may stand upon it.  
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be made of bronze properly; and let the extremities of them be triangular with the same subtlety, and the extremity pointed. 
Formae magda.	Forms of a well. 
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the care of flesh born on the nose.  
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIV.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	Sometimes there are born in the nose various added fleshes, from which there is something that resembles a scorpion of many feet; and from it is cancerous flesh, stony, of a dark color; and from it is that which is soft flesh, not of a dark color. 
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	Therefore, in that which is of these fleshes soft, not deceitful, nor cancerous, it is necessary that you make him sit weak between your hands opposite the sun, and open his nostrils, and project a hook into those fleshes: then draw them outwards, and cut what you have grasped from them with a fine sharp scalpel on one side, until you know that all the flesh has already been removed. 
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	But if there should remain something of it whose incision is not possible: then scrape that with one of the subtle instruments easily, until nothing remains of it.  
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	But if blood should overpower you, or a hot abscess should occur: then oppose to it what is necessary: or if it is from malignant abscesses, then hurry in cauterizing it until the blood is cut off, and all the flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then vinegar and water, or wine, should be poured into the nose after the incision. 
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	But if the nose opens and moisture proceeds from it as far as the palate, then you know that it is already healed. 
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	But if the moisture does not penetrate as it should, then you know that there is flesh grown within it upon the upper bones of the nose, to which the instrument did not reach with the incision. 
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Then it is necessary that you insert a linen thread which has a certain thickness and many knots in it, placing a finger's breadth or less between each knot; and  you must guide the feeble-minded man so he inserts one end of the thread into his nose with a reed, or whatever else is possible for him after he has made it like an awl; and he draws out his own scent until it reaches the palate, and exits over his throat. 
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And indeed they often do this very thing to young boys in schools; and it is an easy matter for him who wishes to do so. 
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place the two ends of the thread, one end which exits above the nose and the other which remains in the nose. 
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then apply a flesh-hook with the knots on the thread. 
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is already caught with the knots of the thread.  
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then pull out the thread; and after washing away the blood, place licorice which you have steeped in Egyptian ointment into the nose. Do this for three days or more, until the ointment eats away all that remains of the flesh. 
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Finally, at the end of the treatment, place a lead tube into the nose for several days until it heals. 
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	But if it needs drier care, use that. 
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	To make a head-plunger with which oils and other medicines are distilled into the nose, make it from silver or bronze; let it be like a small lamp, open like a scallop shell, and its passageway similar. 
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed cannula, like a reed. 
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the shell of the instrument for making a head bandage should be full, open; to which there should be a handle at its end, with which you hold it when you heat oil or whatever you wish from juices and flowing things in it. 
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the shape of the instrument. 
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	Concerning the care of a broken nose. 
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV. 
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Very often a swelling arises at the end of the nose, and it magnifies and increases with the days until its appearance is foul. 
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And therefore it is necessary that you cut into it at the beginning of its appearance and eradicate all of it. 
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place either a cautery or a burning medicine on the spot which takes its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	But if the incision is delayed until it magnifies, then consider, if it is stony, hard, dark colored, and has little feeling: then do not touch it with iron; for it is a cancerous swelling. 
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For I have often seen those who cut into such a swelling, and great harm befell him who had it. 
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the swelling is soft to the touch, not dark-colored, and you see that incision is possible throughout all of it, then evacuate the weak part and cut into it without fear, without dread; and care for the spot with something that dries and constricts until it is healed. 
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	Concerning the suturing of the nose, lip, and ear. 
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.  
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	Know that when a break in continuity occurs in one of these cartilages, little benefit results from an operation except in some individuals.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when it happens to someone that they have one of these injuries, you must consider if it is a recent wound with its own blood; then join the two lips of the wound with suture; then care for it until it is healed. 
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the continuity of the solution has already been separated at its lips and each part has become healthy, then it is necessary to flay all the parts from their own apparent skin until it bleeds. 
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then join the two lips with suture and tighten them, and sprinkle dragon's blood and ground frankincense upon it; and place upon the powders a piece of diaphanicon plaster and some other of the consolidating plasters; and leave it bound for two days or three.  
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then unbind it and change the medicine; and leave it until the threads fall away by themselves. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.  
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of suture is to join the continuity of the solution either with needles as we have described in suturing the abdomen or to join the solution with thread as I have taught you.  
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	On the Extraction of Nodes from the Lips
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people indeed have hard boils resembling grains of herb, often in the inner parts of their lips; and some of these are smaller, and others larger. 
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore it is necessary to turn the lip and cut upon each node of it, and to hang it with a hook, and to cut into it from every side. 
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the place after cutting with ground terebinth until the blood is stopped.  
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then wash it with vinegar and care for the place with it, because of its astringency, until the wounds are healed. 
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	On the Incision of Flesh Born Upon the Gum.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Very often flesh grows upon the gum, which the ancients call abuluss
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore it is necessary that you hang it with a hook or hold it with forceps and cut into it at its root, and let the serum or blood flow. 
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then place on the spot ground saw dust, or other astringent drying powders. 
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	But if that flesh returns after healing, for it often does, then cut it a second time and cauterize it; for it will not return after cautery.  
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	On the reason of Teeth with Iron. 
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX. 
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	Sometimes crusts rough and unsightly gather on the surfaces of teeth, both inner and outer, and sometimes they become blackened and turn yellow, and green, until corruption from them reaches the gum, and the teeth become foul through it. 
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	It is therefore necessary for you to make the weak person sit between your hands, and place his head in your lap, and scrape the tooth with a millstone, in which crusts appear to you like sand; until nothing remains of them, and do likewise with blackness, greenness, yellowness and others until they are clean.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	Therefore if what is in them from the beginning of the reason is removed it is good; and if not then repeat the reasoning on them another day, a second and third until finally you achieve your aim in that which you desire.  
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And know that a tooth needs razors of various shapes and many figures according to what is prepared for your operation; therefore the razor with which the tooth is scraped from the lower part is different from the razor with which it is scraped between the teeth, according to other forms.  
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these shapes of razors should be prepared by you, as you see them. 
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	On the Extraction of Toothache. 
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX. 
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary for you to cure the tooth from its pain with all your skill, and delay in its extraction.  
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For there is nothing to replace it when it is extracted; because it is a noble substance: until there is no excuse for its extraction, then it is necessary when the weak person is compelled to extract it, that you strengthen and assure yourself of the aching tooth. 
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	Very often pain deceives the sick person and he thinks it is in a strong tooth and extracts it; then the pain does not go away until the weak tooth is extracted. 
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	For we have already seen that from the operation of those who cut veins. 
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	Therefore when a tooth that is aching itself is shown to you, it is necessary that you make incisions around the tooth with a scalpel, in which there is some strength, until the gum is loosened from every part: then move it yourself with your fingers, or with delicate forceps at first gradually, until you shake it. 
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place large forceps in it with a good hold, and the head of the weak tooth between your knees: which you have now held well so that it does not move: then pull the tooth according to straightness so as not to break it. 
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if it does not come out, then take one of those instruments and insert it under it from every side with ease, and try its motion as you did at first. 
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	But if the tooth is perforated or corroded, then it is necessary that you fill that hole with cloth and tie it with the end of a thin ray, so that it does not break in the hour of your constriction upon it with forceps. 
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And it is necessary that you act with much care in the incision around the gum from every side.  
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And guard your strength so that you do not break it and a part of it remains, and returns upon the weak one from that evil which is greater than its first pain. 
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And beware lest you do what ignorant phlebotomists do in their haste and boldness concerning its eradication beyond what we have related. 
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	For very often they cause great infirmities to happen upon men, which are more difficult to break and the roots of it all remain or some of them, or that they extract it with some bones of the jawbone, as we have testified many times.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then after its removal it should be washed with wine, or with vinegar and salt. 
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If it should happen that there is a flow of blood from the places (for this often happens) then apply something from zedoary and fill the place with it: and if not, cauterize it if you do not have zedoary. 
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The shape of the forceps which moves a tooth shall first be of long shanks, short handles, thick, so that they do not bend when pressed upon the tooth: let them be as you see with thick handles so that when you squeeze them they do not give way nor double: of short shanks and made of good iron or of well-made steel, straight shanks; and at their ends shall be teeth, some which enter others and constrict with a proper force. 
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes the ends are made like the beak of a bird which is called a stork and they are of strong constriction. 
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	On the removal of teeth, and the extraction of fractured bones of the jaw.  
Caput XXXI.	Chapter Thirty-One. 
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When there remains something broken at the removal of a tooth then it is necessary to put a poultice with butter upon the place for one or two days until the place is softened; then introduce an elevator, or forceps into it, whose ends are assimilated to the beak of a bird which is called a stork.  
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	This is the shape of these forceps. 
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Let their ends be made like a file inside: or like a small sickle.  
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not yield to you with these forceps then you must carefully cut the flesh over the root and insert an instrument called a small lever, whose shape is this: 
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Let it have a short shank, slightly thick, and let it not be wet so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If therefore the root comes out through this, it is good; and if not, you must help with these other instruments whose shapes are these. 
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The shape of the first triangular extremity, in which there is a certain thickness. 
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The shape of the subtle triangular extremity. 
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	It is also joined with this instrument having two branches, which has this form. 
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and tools which preceded in the matter of teeth. 
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	It should also be joined with this instrument which is assimilated to a large hook, of this form, a twisted triangular extremity, in which there is a certain thickness so that it does not break, and let it not be imbibed.  
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that dental instruments are many, and likewise the remaining instruments are not counted, and a prudent artisan, subtle in his art, finds an instrument for himself according to what the operation and illnesses themselves signify to him. 
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Because from illnesses there are those to which the ancients did not say an instrument, on account of the diversity of their species. 
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	But if the jawbone breaks from the mandible or from other bones of the mouth, or it rots: then carefully examine it in its place with what suits it from instruments and forceps which I said in the extraction of roots, and join it with a gesture, which has this form.  
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Let it have a certain gradual thickness so that it is strung or held with the bone and does not flee and wander until the bone comes out; and restore the place with appropriate medicines for that. 
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there is a small putrefaction in the bone, then scrape it from its putrefaction and care for it until it heals. 
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Of the Locking of Teeth Prominent Above Others.  
Caput XXXII.	Chapter Thirty-Two. 
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth protrude not according to their natural course, it becomes ugly by that: and especially when it happens in women, and girls, namely, those of marriageable age. 
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore, it is necessary for you to consider. 
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	If a tooth arises after another and is not positioned, or it is possible to file it down, but the tooth cannot be filed: then eradicate it. And if it is joined with another tooth, then cut it out with this instrument, which has this shape. 
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a small beak and is made of hard iron, with a very sharp point. 
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	Let your incision be such that you cut it over many days, and because of the hardness of the tooth, so that another is not moved from the teeth. 
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	But if it is prominent and exposed for filing: then file it with a file of hard iron, which has this shape. 
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Let it be entirely of iron, and its handle of very small points, like the file with which needles are made: with which the tooth should be filed gradually over many days with ease, so that the tooth is not moved and falls out; then smooth it, and finally eradicate it with certain razors.  
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	But if there is a tooth from which a part breaks off and injures the tongue: then it is necessary that you file it also until the roughness of that fracture is removed and it is made even; and smoothed so that it does not injure the tongue nor corrupt speech.  
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	Concerning the Retention of Teeth with Gold Wires. 
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter Thirty-Three. 
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When the front teeth suffer a concussion and jolting from a blow or fall, and the infirm person cannot bite down on it so that it does not come loose; and you have treated them with astringent medicines, but the treatment has not been effective: then there is a plan to bind them with a gold wire, because silver turns green and rots after a few days, but gold never changes. 
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the wire be medium in subtlety and thickness according to the amount that fits between the teeth. 
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the form of retention indeed is, that you take a wire and insert a double length of it between two healthy teeth; then weave with the two ends of the wire among the loose teeth, whether there is one or more, until you reach with the wire to a healthy tooth on the other side. 
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the texture up to the part from which you began; and tighten your hand with subtlety and wisdom, until it is completely removed; and let your constriction where you are stringing the thread be at the roots of the teeth, so that it does not come loose. 
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut off the superfluous ends of the thread with forceps; and join both, and turn them over with your hand; and conceal them between a healthy tooth and a moved tooth, so that it does not injure the tongue; then let it remain thus tightened. 
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	But if they become loosened, or broken, tighten them with another thread, and it will stand thus for the whole time.  
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the form of Teeth, and the figure of the retention of two sound teeth, and two moved teeth, as you see. 
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes it happens that one tooth, or two return after falling out and into their places, and are retained as we have described, and remain; and this is not done except by a craftsman, prudent, and experienced. 
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes one of the vaccine bones is adapted; and it is made into the shape of a tooth, and placed in its place, from which the tooth is fortified and tightened, as we said; and it remains, and is used with it for a long time.  
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	Concerning the cutting of a ligament that occurs under the tongue, and prohibits speech. 
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter Thirty-Four. 
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Sometimes this ligament that occurs under the tongue is either natural, with which a man is born, or accidental, from a wound that has already consolidated. 
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation on it is that you open the mouth of the infirm one in his head in your lap, and raise his tongue; then cut that nervous ligament across its width, until the tongue is loosened from its restraint. 
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	But if there is something hard and knotty in it, and it is from the consolidation of a wound; then project a hook into it, and pierce it across its width, until you strike the ligament, and the knot is loosened. 
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And take care that there is not a fissure into the depth of the flesh, and you cut an artery there, and bleeding should occur. 
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then it should be washed in the trace of the incision with rose water, or vinegar, or cold water.  
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place under the tongue a ligature from linen, which the weak person should hold in every night so that it does not become consolidated on the second day. 
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	But if bleeding should occur, then place over the spot boiled zedoary. 
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if blood overcomes you, then cauterize the place with a lenticular cautery, which is suitable for that; then care for it with the remaining care until it heals. 
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	On the Extraction of a Ranula Which Occurs Under the Tongue.  
Caput XXXV.	Chapter Thirty-Five. 
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	Sometimes it happens that under the tongue there occurs a swelling which is similar to a small frog, preventing the tongue from its natural operation; and perhaps it grows so much that it fills the mouth.  
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation on it is that you open the weak person's mouth before the sun, and consider the swelling. 
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If therefore you see it of a dark color, or black, hard, to which the weak person does not find sensation; then do not touch it, because it is cancer. 
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it is inclined towards whiteness, in which there is moisture; then project into it a hook, and cut it with a fine scalpel, and free it from every part. 
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	And if blood overcomes you in the hour of your operation, then place over it boiled zedoary until the blood is cut off; then return to your operation until you extract it with all its complement.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then wash it with vinegar and salt; and care for it with the remaining suitable care for that until it heals. 
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	On the Care of a Swelling of Two Tonsils.  
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter Thirty-Six. 
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	Sometimes there occur between the throat glands, which resemble almonds, that protrude outward; and they are called two tonsils: when you treat these as we have said in the division, and they do not heal, then consider. 
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	Therefore if it is a hard abscess, dark in color, with little sensation: then do not touch it with iron. 
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is reddish in color, and its root is thick: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing a flow of blood, but rather let it alone until it matures. 
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then either you will pierce it, or it will break open on its own. 
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is white in color, round, and its root is slender: then it is necessary to cut into it.  
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation on it is, that you consider before your operation whether its hot abscess has quieted with rest completely, or diminishes somewhat: then therefore make the sick person sit before the sun, and let his head be in your lap; and open his mouth, and let a servant receive between his hands, and press his tongue down with an instrument, which has this shape.  
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Let it be made of silver, or bronze, that is thin like a knife. 
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When therefore you press with it the tongue, and the abscess is shown to you, and your sight falls upon it: then take a hook, and fix it in the tonsil, and draw it outward as much as you can, besides that you pull out with it some of the tunics. 
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut into it with an instrument which has this following shape.  
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It resembles forceps: but nevertheless let its points be curved, so that the opening of each one is in a straight line with the other acutely; therefore take care that it be made of tempered iron, or aluminum imbued.  
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	But if this instrument is not present, then cut into it with a scalpel, which has this shape.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	Let it be sharp on one side and not sharp on the other. 
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you have cut one amygdala, cut the other according to this same kind of incision. 
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision, let the patient gargle with cold water, or with vinegar and water.  
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there should happen to him a flow of blood, let him gargle with water in which pomegranate rinds have been boiled, or myrtle leaves and those like them from astringents, until the flow of blood is stopped; then care for him until he is healed. 
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And sometimes other abscesses arise in the throat besides the two amygdales.  
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Therefore cut them according to what I said in the incision of the two amygdales equally. 
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And I myself have already treated a woman for an abscess that had arisen between her throat, which was dragging it to suffocation, with few senses, because it had almost closed the throat; and the woman was breathing from a narrow passage, and had already forbidden her both food and drink of water; and she had already come to death if she had remained one day or two days. 
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the abscess had risen so much that it had sent out two branches until they had gone out above the two nostrils.  
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	Therefore I hurried quickly and fixed a hook into one of them. 
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I drew it out, and a large portion was drawn from it.  
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut it where I grasped it from the nostril. 
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I did that same thing to her from the other nostril.  
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened her mouth and pressed her tongue; and afterward I fixed a hook into the abscess itself; then I cut off a part of it, and there did not flow from it except for a little blood. Therefore the woman's throat was completely opened, and she immediately began to drink water, and then took food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	Therefore I did not cease to cut from that abscess many times over a long period; and the abscess would succeed in the place where I was cutting, until it was prolonged excessively and came out with her. 
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	Therefore I ingeniously cauterized the abscess between the throat. 
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	So it remained from addition; then I walked away, and I did not know what God did with it after me. 
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On the incision of an abscess of the uvula.  
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter Thirty-Seven. 
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When catarrh descends to the uvula and becomes abscessed and is long, then it is called perpendicular; and if it is in the lower part thick, round, then it is called a uva.  
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is treated with what we said in the division, and the treatment does not avail; and you see that the hot abscess has subsided from it, and it is subtle: then it is necessary that you incise it. 
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And that which is gathered round from it, and there is no length to it, and it is bloody, or dusky colored, or black, and there is no sensation to it: then it is necessary that you avoid the incision of it. 
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For in this there is fear over the weak one.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Therefore it is necessary when you see it according to the manner which I said from its whiteness and length, that you make the weak one sit before the sun; and press their tongue with an instrument of which narration preceded: then fix a hook in the uvula and draw it downward: and incise it with one of two instruments which I said in the incision of two tonsils.  
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary that you not incise from it except what is added beyond the natural limit without addition. 
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you incise from it more, you injure the voice and speech.  
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision use what we narrated in the incision of two tonsils; and care for it until it heals.  
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	But if the weak one is terrified from the incision, then it is necessary that you use ingenuity in its cauterization without fear and dread.  
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the manner of cautery in this is not except with sharp water; and it is, that you place the head of the weak one in your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press his tongue with the instrument we have mentioned. 
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water which I told you in the chapter on cauterization and mix it with a calx that has not been extinguished and make it neither thick nor thin and fill the cavity of this instrument, which has this shape. 
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Let the extremity in which the medicine is placed have a cavity like the cavity of a ray's ear. 
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine on his tongue; and let the sick person lie on his side so that saliva runs from his mouth from within the medicine, so that nothing descends from it to his throat and harms him.  
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine. 
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first place it on his tongue for half an hour, until you see it already blackened and the bite of the medicine subdued. 
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take cotton and wrap it around the extremity of the ray and infuse the cotton with the medicine and insert the ray with the cotton into the cannula from above until the cotton adheres to the tongue.  
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do that many times until you achieve what you desire from the cauterization of the vein. 
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then let it go; for it will dry up and fall off after three or four days. 
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	And if it is necessary for you to iterate the medicine, iterate it; and after cauterization cleanse around the vein with cotton steeped in butter, and purify what is around it from the medicine; and wash with cold water. 
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And let it be treated externally with embrocations, and internally with gargles until it is healed.  
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This therefore is a healthier kind of treatment than incision and further from fear.
