Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes the tongue is also cured with something more subtle than cautery and incision; for it is cured with fumigation according to this method. 
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamint, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and sage, and chamomile, and abrotanum, and herbs like these; and put them all together, or some of them in a pot, and submerge them with vinegar, and let them boil; and the pot should be smeared with clay neatly; and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, above which an instrument concave is to be placed according to this manner. 
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made of silver, or bronze; and insert the extremity, in which there is a pomegranate seed, into the mouth of the sick person, until the vapor rises to the uvula above the cannula, until the uvula is darkened much. 
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over it many times, until it dries up.  
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware, lest you do this treatment at the beginning of the arrival of an abscess. 
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For it most often adds to the abscess; and it is not necessary for you to do that except at the decline of its heat.  
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if this instrument is not present to you, then take a cannula, and compose bark of the fig tree in its extremity; so that the mouth of the sick person is not burned; for the bark of the fig tree prevents the vapor from burning the mouth; and this is from good treatment with safety. 
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the Extraction of Thorns, and Bones from the Throat. 
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.  
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Often a bone, or a fishbone, or something else adheres in the throat. 
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore it is necessary for you to extract what of them appears above which the sight falls upon, after you press the tongue with an instrument toward the sun, and it is made clear to you what is in the throat. 
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what does not appear to you and is concealed in the throat, it is necessary for you to make the sick person vomit before food is digested in the stomach. 
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	For perhaps the attached thing will go out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Either the weak person swallows a piece of turnip or a lettuce root or he swallows a mouthful of dry bread; or he takes a piece of dried sea sponge which is soft and ties it on a thread, then swallows it. 
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	And when therefore it reaches the place where the spines or bone are, and is drawn out, then it comes out.  
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore it does not come out with what we have said, then use an instrument of lead according to this form. 
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than the radius a little and let there be a curve at its extremity which it introduces into his throat with ease; and let he himself have his head elevated upward. 
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him beware of touching his epiglottis so that he does not have a coughing fit and he pushes with it the mouth or the spine or the doctor introduces it himself with his hand. 
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But what the weak person introduces is better because of his knowledge of the place of the thing attached and he pushes it down or pulls his hand up with the instrument all the way according to the quantity prepared for him until it comes out.  
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the Extraction of a Leech. 
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX. 
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When a leech is applied with what I said in the division on treatment with medicines and it does not detach itself then consider in the throat of the weak person in front of the sun or by the sun after you have pressed his tongue with the instrument which I related to you.  
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your sight falls upon the leech extract it with a small hook or with delicate forceps carefully.  
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	And if it is not possible to do so with them then take a concave tube and introduce it into the throat of the weak person up to near the throat; then introduce into the concavity of the tube iron heated with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do that many times and let the weak person abstain from all water for the whole day. 
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then he should take a cup full of cold water and open his mouth in it; and gargle with it, but not swallow anything from it; and stir the water with his hand one hour after another. 
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech immediately falls when it feels the water. 
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it does not come out with what we have described, then fumigate the weak one with bugs, or with asafoetida with the instrument which I have described in the fumigation of the uvula. 
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do that many times, for it will fall by itself. 
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in fumigation is that you should take a jar, in which there are live plums with fire; and let the jar be covered with a lid, in the middle of which there is a hole; and let the end of the instrument be placed in that hole. 
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then direct the fumigation, and let the weak one place his mouth at the end of the cannula, and close his mouth so that the fumigation does not escape until you know that the fumigation has already reached the leech. 
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech immediately falls. 
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	But if it does not fall, then repeat the fumigation many times.  
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the weak one endure thirst, and eat salt, and garlic, and not drink water. 
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he comes out with this regimen. 
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which the leech is extracted from the throat when it falls on top of the vision.  
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to forceps, as you see: except that it has this curve which is inserted into the throat. 
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end is similar to the beak of a bird which is called a stork, in which there is roughness like a file; when it grasps something, it does not let go of it at all.  
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the opening of abscesses, and their incision, and care in general. 
Caput XL.	Chapter 40. 
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of abscesses, of many types, according to how we remember them, namely one, and one in this book; and they are different in their perforation and incision in two ways. 
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of which is from the type of abscess itself, and because it consists of humors. 
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second way is because of the places where they occur in the body. 
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For an abscess occurring on the head is different from an abscess occurring in the anus; and an abscess occurring in a fleshy place is different from an abscess occurring in the joints; and each of them has its own judgment according to its operation.  
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And of abscesses, there are some which ought not to be perforated except after the ripening of blood in them and its completion; and of these, there are some which ought to be perforated while they are raw and do not ripen according to their completion. 
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Such as abscesses which are near the joints. 
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when an abscess occurs near a joint and is prolonged to be its own, until it putrifies what is around it, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint are corrupted; therefore, it is the cause of closer contraction of that limb. 
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or there is an abscess at a principal limb; for if you delay its perforation until it ripens, it will harm either that or the principal limb through it.  
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is near the anus, therefore perforate it while immature; and you ought not to perforate a raw abscess, not of complete digestion, except that which is near the anus, lest it putrefy deeply and extend to the interior parts of the anus and become a fistula, or becomes incurable at its end. 
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You ought to know the hour of perforating an abscess which has ripened according to its completion; and it is at sedation of pain, recession of fever, and diminution of redness, and throbbing, and sharpness of the head of the abscess; and the other signs. 
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is necessary that you make the same perforation in the lower place of the abscess, and of the more prominent eminence; and let the perforation be directed in length of the body, if the abscesses are in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of tendons, and cords, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all equal places where there is no reflection. 
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those which are reflected, proceed with the perforation according to that member. 
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	But when an abscess is in fleshy places: then it is better that you leave its perforation alone until its digestion is confirmed, as we said according to the complement. 
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you pierce it before that, the course of the virus is prolonged from it, and there is much filth and foulness, and perhaps the lips of it will become hardened, and its depth. 
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And certain abscesses are perforated according to the width of the body as needed: or according to that which the member requires. 
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer a small perforation in small abscesses, and a large perforation in large abscesses: or many incisions through similarity of the size of the abscess. 
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are abscesses from which it is necessary that the skin be concave: and it is cut when already made like cloth, and made at the end, which already is dead: such as happens in many, like a hernia, and buboes. 
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And from those are those which are cut with an incision having three angles.  
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And from those is one from which it is cut like the figure of a myrtle leaf. 
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like an abscess of the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And from those are those in which a round incision and a crescent incision are administered: and similar to those from incisions. 
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	But that which does not have a head, such as soft, superficial abscesses, it is necessary that you pierce it with a superficial perforation, or only a flat one.  
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary, when the abscess is large and has already collected much pus, and you pierce it, that you do not hurry and draw out all the pus at that time; rather, draw out a part of it. 
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then stitch up the abscess until another day. 
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then again draw out some pus. 
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the degree until it comes out; especially if the patient is weak of body, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an old man: for the animal spirit is often resolved with the exit of pus; and perhaps the patient dies, and you do not perceive. 
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore be very careful in this chapter.  
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you pierce it by which you pierce these abscesses, it is necessary that you wash the wound and consider.  
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	And if therefore the wound of the abscess is small, or the incision is flat, then apply a bandage from linen, or old cotton. 
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if the abscess is large, and there are many fissures from the perforation, it is necessary then that you insert into every fissure a bandage until they reach one another. 
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have cut off a part of the skin in the abscess, or hollowed it around: then it is necessary that you fill it with old cotton, or as when cloth is woven, or shaved with linen fluff without moisture; and tighten it until the third day. 
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then throw it off, and care for it with what is necessary from ointment until it heals.  
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if bleeding should occur during the hour of your operation, then apply cold water and vinegar, after a cloth is soaked in them; and place it upon the place of bleeding many times. 
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the bleeding persists, then it is necessary that you administer treatment and care, and powders, which I have related in many places of this book of ours, and by division. 
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If, however, it is wintertime and the place of the abscess is full of nerves, then you must pour warm broth with wine and oil upon it and place them over the area. 
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is summertime and the areas are fleshy, then you must place compresses soaked in water and oil, or wine and oil, upon them entirely cold. 
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we have said, then you must open the abscess and cleanse it, and administer to its cure what is suitable for it until it is healed. 
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This, therefore, is all that is necessary from the knowledge of treating abscesses universally. 
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the path of distinction, I have already spoken about every abscess and how its cure is approached chapter by chapter individually. 
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the incision of abscesses which occur on the skin of the head.  
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41. 
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small abscesses occur on the skin of the head, and they are of the kinds of nodules, which contain sheaths that are like sacks to them, as if they were poultices of hens. 
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of them. 
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Some of them are fatty; some contain moisture like slime; some contain moisture like curds and pulps, and those similar; and some are hard and stony.  
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the incision of all of them and their extraction there is no fear, as long as an artery does not oppose during their incision. 
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in incising them is to test them with an instrument whose shape comes after this, which is called an Intromissum, until you know what it contains. 
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it is one that contains moisture, then dry it with a longitudinal incision, shallow in depth, according to this form. 
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with an incision from line b to line g. When, therefore, the moisture is evacuated, then remove the skin that contains it and do not leave anything behind in it. 
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For it often returns if something remains from it. 
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the dressing in Egyptian ointment, if it is present; and if not, in water and salt; and fill the wound with it, and leave it until another day.  
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it will corrode what remains from the cyst. 
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the dressing on it with a second Egyptian ointment, and a third, and if it does not digest with that, until you are confident that nothing remains from the cyst, then heal the wound with ointment until it is cured. 
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	But if the abscess contains a fatty node, then dry it according to this manner, with an incision in the shape of a cross; and insert hooks between the two lips of the incision, and flay it from every part; and exert your strength in extracting the tunic which contains it. 
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if an artery opposes you, then do what I will tell you after.  
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And do likewise in a stony abscess, from an incision and the same treatment, according to what we have said.  
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the incision over a stony abscess is easier; because it has little blood and moisture. 
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain of these abscesses which are on the head in some people with which there is no moisture at all.  
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	For it is this: because I cut on an abscess on the head of a young woman, and found the abscess like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken; and if anyone struck it with something throwing, he would wound himself.  
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But in other abscesses which happen on the head, except these abscesses which happen on children's heads, and at the roots of the ears, let the incision of all of them be a superficial one. 
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or always make a perforation of them from their lower part so that the course of blood is relieved downwards.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for it with what suits them from treatment. 
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	On the Section of Strangulation in the Neck. 
Caput XLII.	Chapter Forty-Two. 
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These swellings often occur in the neck, and under the armpits, and groins; and sometimes they occur in the rest of the body. 
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And regarding those which occur in the neck from them, they are one, and many; and they are generated from each other; and every swelling from them is within its own tunic, just as it is in knots and swellings of the head, as we have narrated. 
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the kinds of these swellings are many. 
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And of them indeed are stony ones; and of them are those which contain moisture; and of them are malignant ones, which do not obey treatment. 
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Therefore, in that which you see of them of good disposition to the touch, whose proximity to the color of the skin is manifest, and moves in every direction, and is not joined with the nerves of the neck, nor with the gullet, nor with the artery, and is not deep: it is necessary that you section it superficially from the upper part to the lower part of the body from line, b. to line, g.; and flay it from every side; and extend two lips of skin with a hook, or with many hooks if needed by it, as we have said in swellings of the head, and extract it gradually. 
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is for caution that a vein or nerve not be cut. 
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the scalpel not be very sharp so that it does not add to your hand with the incision, or disturb the sick person, and you cut what is not necessary. 
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut a vein or artery, or it prevents you from the operation, then place in the wound chewed oak, or certain powders which stanch blood, and constrict the wound, and leave it until the sharpness of the swelling subsides, and the wound softens: or until it begins and wants to putrefy. 
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is severed by a tunic, therefore return to your operation until you finish it. 
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your index finger if anything remains from the small ligatures; therefore cut them and clean them. 
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	But if there is a large vein in the root of the ligature then it is necessary that you do not cut that ligature from its root; rather it is necessary that you tie it with a strong doubled thread, and let it fall off by itself without harm. 
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old fat which you have already submerged in Egyptian ointment. 
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of it yourself. 
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole ligature is cut, then it is necessary that you bring together the two lips of the wound and sew it up immediately after you see that there is absolutely no excess remaining. 
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that excess remains because of the size of the ligature then it is necessary for you to intend to cut its root and remove it; and administer the suture which we have described. 
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And that which the ligature contains of moisture, perforate it with a superficial perforation so that the place of its maturity appears to you and place the perforation from that which follows below the body as we have said. 
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the perforation lint with ointment and the like so that it corrodes what remains from decay until when you see that the wound is already cleansed; then take care of it with a flesh-generating ointment until it is healed.  
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the incision of the epiglottis from an abscess within the throat by accident. 
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43. 
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients said this incision was made on the epiglottis and I have not seen anyone in our land who has done it; and this is the writing of their speech. 
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in those who have synanche, it is necessary that the epiglottis be cut; since benefit is not made through it because all the veins and lungs are weak. 
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a hot apostema in the mouth, or throat, or both almonds, when there is no pain in the canal, it is necessary to use the section of the epiglottis, to avoid the destruction which arises from pre-speech. 
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we wish to do this, it is necessary to cut the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small incision across its width, in the space between two circles, so that the incision be made in flesh, not cartilage; and indeed this place is suitable for the incision because it is private of flesh, and blood vessels are distant from it.  
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	But if the practitioner is timid, then it is necessary for him to extend the skin of the throat with a hook. 
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he should grasp the skin until he reaches the canal; divert the blood vessels if he sees anything from them. 
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he should cut the flesh as we have described; and it is shown above the incision of the canal from phlegm that issues forth from it, with what is broken up, and cessation of voice.  
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the wound open for some time. 
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the hour arrives in which pre-speech is feared, bring together the two lips of the wound of the skin, and sew it alone without cartilage.  
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines that promote the growth of flesh until it heals. 
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of this discourse which we have recounted is not explained except when they see that one of these apostemas has already coalesced the throat of the sick person; and he is raised up on the brink of death, and desires to interrupt his breathings: they go to cut the epiglottis so that the sick person may breathe upon the wound with a certain respiration and be saved from death; and for this reason they prescribed leaving the wound open until the malice of the sickness is consumed, and its malice is three days, and as if it were itself; then therefore they prescribed suturing the wound and taking care of it until it heals. 
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And what I myself have seen is that one maidservant took a knife and thrust it into her throat, and with it she struck part of the pulmonary canal. 
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was summoned to treat her, and I found her groaning, as is the groan of one dying.  
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I therefore examined the wound, and I found that little blood had come out from it. 
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I was therefore perplexed, because she had not severed a vein, nor a sinew; and wind was escaping from the wound.  
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I hastened therefore and sewed up her wound, and I cared for it until it was healed; and nothing happened to the maidservant except hoarseness in her voice; and after a few days she returned to a better state of health.  
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore I say from this: that there is no fear in the incision of the epiglottis. 
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the incision of a hernia of the throat. 
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter Forty-four.  
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This swelling called a hernia of the throat is a large swelling, according to the color of the body; and it is common in women.  
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it occurs in two ways: either it is natural; or it is accidental. 
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural kind, there certainly is no artifice.  
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental kind, however, occurs in two ways, one of which is similar to fatty nodules. 
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other way is similar to a swelling that arises from the knotting of an artery.  
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is fear in this case and it should not be presumed to be incised with iron unless it is small; and you must examine it and investigate it with a probe.  
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find it similar to a fatty nodule and it is not suspended with any veins; then cut it out as nodules are cut; and extract it with what it contains from the cyst if it is in a cyst; and if it is not, then carefully examine all of it.  
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with what is necessary for healing, until it heals. 
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On the Section of Kinds of Nodes. 
Caput XLV.	Chapter Forty-Five.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of nodes, and I have already mentioned all their kinds in the division; and it is necessary that I tell here the difference between a node and an excrescence: since there is a doubt-causing one. 
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore that when there is an excrescence, there is heat and fever and violent pains until the boiling of the superfluity subsides and putrefaction is completed; then indeed the fevers and heat subside. 
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But with a node there is no heat, nor fever, nor pains, and it contains them in sacs sifachin, which is their own sac, and it is according to the color of the body: and the beginning of them is like a chickpea, and it becomes like a date stone, larger and smaller.  
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are according to two kinds: either fatty; or containing moisture. 
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of the moisture are many, according to what I said in the division.  
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore it is necessary that when you arrive at the treatment of a node, you should examine it and inquire into it first with an instrument called an intromissor, according to what its form will come to be in the chapter which is after this.  
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of inquiry for abscesses and all nodes is to take this instrument and insert it into the damper place which you find in the abscess; and turn your fingers with it gradually until you know that the instrument has already penetrated the skin. 
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then finally measure your hand according to the measure of the size of the abscess.  
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then draw out the intromissor and consider that which comes forth in its trace. 
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore moisture flows out, whatever the color may be; then dry it with a superficial incision, according to what I said in the other abscesses. 
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if the moisture does not flow out in the track of the Intromissi, then know that it is fat; therefore cut upon it a section in the shape of a cross, according to this form as I have taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and flay the skin from every part with ease; and keep a kistin if you can over it, so as to draw out the entire one healthy with a knot. 
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the kistin is broken at the operation and it is not possible to extract it whole, for this often happens, then draw it out in pieces until nothing remains of it. 
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if a little or much of it remains, the Knot returns most often.  
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	And if it overcomes you and a little remains from it: then fill the wound upon your completion with certain corrosive sharp powders; and constrict the wound and put upon it something that sits hot poultice, and care for it with the rest of the cure until it heals. 
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	But if the Knot is large, then cut its two lips, and care for it as it incorporates.  
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if a vein contrary to you pulsates or does not pulsate, then hurry and fill the place with triturated zegi, and leave it constricted for two days or three until the wound putrefies and the ebullition of blood subsides; then return to cutting what remains from the Knot. 
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Concerning external instruments for incision and perforation.  
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI. 
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	Of these are the forms of Intromissis and they are of three species.  
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For among them is a large one, and among them is a medium one, and among them is a small one. 
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be made of sharp square-ended iron so they quickly enter the abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of Experimenters, or rather, perforators, and one of them is called a beris, that is, a perforator, and they are of three species. 
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For from them there is a large one, a medium one, and a small one. 
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	It is agreed that they should be investigated through them abscesses, and fistulas, and buboes from that which is between them of bones.  
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, and polished, like large needles with which cushions are sewn, namely from citron, or from bronze, or iron, or silver. 
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the best of them are those that are made from citron. 
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And experience is also made from black lead, which are suitable for experimenting with fistulas, whose concavity has reflections, so that they are reflected with their smoothness with those reflections. 
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And they are again of three kinds. 
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because from them are long ones, medium ones, and short ones, according to the amount of the width of the fistula and its tightness.  
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	Form of Hooks, and they are of many kinds. 
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For from them are simple ones, namely those which have a single curve: and they are of three kinds as you see, Large, Medium, and Small.  
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from them are blind hooks: and they are of three kinds. 
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from them are hooks having two curves, and they are of three kinds: and from them are hooks having three curves, and they are of three kinds: and all these are necessary in their place. 
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of Knives, with which nodes and abscesses are cut and scraped: and they are of three kinds: because from them there is a large one, a medium one, and a small one.  
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their tips with which the cutting is done are sharp, other tips are not sharp: and they are not put thus unless so that with them there is relief in the scraping of nodes when there is fear of cutting a vein or nerve: and so that the weak are healed through them and find a little tranquility from the burning they experience at the scraping of an abscess. 
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are magda, and they are of three kinds. 
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of bronze, and they are similar to a razor, with which alcohol is made: and at the wide end there is a hidden spatulated point: and through it runs inwards, and outwards when you wish, as you see. 
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The spatulated forms which are concealed between the fingers at the perforation of abscesses: and the sick do not perceive them: and they are of three kinds, large, medium, and small. 
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	Forms for drawing out wind with which the flow of blood is severed: and they are of three kinds, large, medium, and small. 
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of bronze, or brass, round, to a length a little as you see: and let them be fine. 
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of wind-drawing instruments be large and small with you: so that you may sever blood quickly when necessary, and then when medicine is not present to you. 
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use them in the cutting of blood in every place in the body, and do not use them except in fleshy places: such as the calves of the leg, and the hip, and the calves of the arms, and the breasts, and the belly, and the groin, and similar places to these, from the fleshy calves, moist.  
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they are made into other small instruments similar to hazelnut shells, according to their shape: with which blood is cut off when it flows from the place of phlebotomy, or at an incision of a vein, or artery: and sometimes they are made round according to this shape. 
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the treatment of the breasts of men which resemble the breasts of women.  
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the nipples of certain men swell up during sleep (that is, when they begin to be excited in sleep) until they resemble women's breasts: and they remain fetid abscesses.  
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Therefore, whoever shuns that, must cut above the nipples with a lunar section, according to this form from line b to line g. Then remove all the fat and skin. 
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill the wound with flesh-colored medicine. 
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the two lips of the wound with suture and care for it until it heals. 
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the nipple descends downwards and softens because of its size, as happens to women: then it must be divided on its two upper sides with two similar lunar incisions, each of which is joined with the other at the ends of each, until there is a larger line containing the smaller one, according to this form from line b to line g. Then remove the skin that is between the two lips and take away the fat and administer what we said about suture and powders, which are necessary for healing, until it heals. 
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	But if you cannot complete the incision as it ought to be made, because of the restlessness of the patient or because of bleeding: then it is necessary to fill the wound with cotton soaked in a corrosive ointment and leave it until it corrodes what remains of the fat. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals. 
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On puncturing an abscess which occurs under the nipple.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses which occur under the nipple are of a kind of hard Strophulus, which contains cysts and some that contain humors. 
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore those which are of the kind that contain humors must be cut with a lunar incision according to this form from line b to line g. And when all that is in the abscess is evacuated as pus, then fill it with old cotton and leave it until the next day. 
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the cotton and treat it with a suitable ointment until it heals.  
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the abscess is of the kind of knots called Strophulas, then split it open above it, as we said in the section on Strophulas equally. 
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	But if the wound extends so as to discharge pus, then apply a cautery to it, according to what we said previously. 
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the incision of an abscess which occurs because of an artery and vein. 
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured and the skin above it becomes consolidated, an abscess often results; similarly, a vein may also develop an abscess and swelling. 
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	The signs by which it is recognized that an abscess and swelling are due to an artery or vein are these: when the abscess is due to an artery, it is long, aggregated deep within the body; and when you press the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there is a grating sensation. 
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to a vein is round and evident on the surface of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	To make an incision on this abscess is an error, especially when it is under the armpits, groins, neck, and in many parts of the body; and it is very large. 
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, it is necessary that its treatment be performed with fire, and what arises from them also at the extremities or in the head must be separated.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	On that which arises from the swelling of an artery opening, make an incision in the skin along its length. 
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with hooks, and then expose the artery; free it from its surrounding tissues until it is exposed.  
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert a needle under it and make it penetrate to the other side, and tie off the artery with two threads in two places, according to what I taught you in the extraction of the two arteries which are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then puncture the area between the two ligatures with a scalpel until all the blood in it has exited and the abscess is resolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply a treatment that produces pus until the ligaments fall away; afterwards treat it with suitable ointments until it is healed. 
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it is an abscess due to a vein being cut, then you must hold with your hand as much as possible from the abscess together with the skin. 
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert a needle under the place which you held with your hand and make it penetrate; and let there be in it a double thread until you draw it out from the other side. 
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie the abscess together with a good ligature, as I told you in regard to a ligature for a vein, from two parts with two ends of thread. 
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	But if you fear that the thread will be pulled out, then insert another needle with another thread under the entire abscess at the needle incision; press and tighten your threads in four places. 
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the abscess in its middle until what is in it comes out; then incise the excess skin and let what is tied be released from it.  
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place upon it a poultice which you have soaked in wine and oil. 
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply a treatment made with lint and ointments until it is healed. 
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	Concerning an abscess which occurs from twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter One.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in an artery and vein, similarly an abscess occurs in nerves; which happens to them by a blow or from excessive labor and the like; and it most often occurs in places of support, such as the heel, and in every place where joints are moved; and it is a serious abscess. 
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color resembles the rest of the body, and it is in many positions without pain; and when it is squeezed with force, a weak person feels a sensation similar to numbness.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not a collected abscess deep within the body; rather, it is under the skin, and it moves to every part, and it does not extend forward or back. 
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore, what is among them at the joints should not be invaded with iron. 
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	For perhaps contraction may occur. 
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which is among them on the head, or on the forehead, find the skin with a spatula. 
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If therefore there is a small abscess, then hold it with forceps, and cut it from the root. 
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook, and flay it: then remove it, and bring the wound together with suture: and care for it until it heals. 
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Concerning the incision of an abscess, which occurs in the abdomen.  
Caput LI.	Chapter LI. 
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	It happens to some men many times in their abdomens, and in the other bodies of theirs, boils, which are called fungal, by similarity of them with fungi. 
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is delicate, and their head is thick, and their lips are inverted.  
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And some of them are small: and some of them grow very large. 
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I indeed already saw a man, and in his abdomen were two boils, which were more similar to fungi than other things: there was no difference between them, white, small-rooted, and their lips were inverted, and they split open, and moisture always flowed from them. 
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I therefore cut into them, and found in the weight of one almost ten and eight ounces and in the other almost six ounces. And the operation in cutting them is that you consider then, if he is weak, moist, and the color of the boil is white, moist, delicate-rooted: then cut it with a broad spatula, and have a cautery in your presence in fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	Very often much blood is expelled at its incision: hasten therefore if blood overcomes you, then cauterize it.  
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	But if you see a weak and timid one from the incision with iron, then take a thread of lead well made, and constrict it with it: whose method is what we said, and let it go for two days. 
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add it to the mold of lead. 
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not cease to press the lead, whenever it prints on the thelil, until it is cut off and falls by itself without effort. 
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the thelil should be of a thick root, then there is some fear and dread in its incision; especially that which is in the belly. 
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	Nevertheless it is possible to cut into half of it.  
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not grow back. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for it until the wound is healed.  
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And be careful not to presume to cut into the thelil which is of a dark color, little feeling, foul appearance; for it is indeed a cancerous swelling; and I shall come with a remembrance of Cancer after this. 
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the treatment of umbilical hernia. 
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.  
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	An umbilical hernia occurs from many causes. 
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from fissures in the diaphragm which is above the belly; and from it exits fat or intestine, according to what happens in other ruptures. 
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood flowing from a Vein or an Artery, according to what was previously stated.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from wind constricted within it. 
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	But if it is because of a fissure in the diaphragm and the exit of fat; then its color is similar to the color of the body; and it is soft, without pain; and appears in various locations. 
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is because of the exit of intestine, then its location, with that which we have narrated, is of more vehement diversity. 
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	Therefore when you press it with your fingers, it disappears; then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it; and it swells greatly at the entrance of the bath, and there is vehement labor. 
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	But if it is because of moisture, it is soft, then it does not disappear when you press it with your hand, nor does it contract or increase. 
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then with these signs an abscess appears darkening from the cleavage. 
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is due to flesh: then the abscess is grave, thick, hard, and is fixed according to a single quantity. 
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	But if it is due to windiness, then its touch is soft. 
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation on that is, that you then consider if the prominence of the umbilicus is due to blood from an Artery or Vein, or windiness: then it is necessary that you prohibit its cure.  
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is fear and dread, as I taught you in the chapter, in which I said abscesses due to artery and vein. 
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	But if the prominence of the umbilicus is due to intestine or mesentery: then it is necessary that you advise the sick person, so that he may hold his breath and stand extended. 
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then mark with a cautery all around the umbilicus.  
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Afterwards instruct him to lie down between your hands on his back. 
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then encircle with a broad spatula all around the umbilicus above the place which you marked with a cautery.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Afterwards extend the middle of the abscess upwards, with a large hook. 
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie it tightly around with thread or cord from silk with a firm bandage: and let the knot of the bandage be distant. 
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle of the extended abscess above the bandage.  
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find it already caught by the bandage: then extract the distant one and insert your index finger into it, and push the intestine towards the interior of the belly: and if you find a mesentery, then take hold of it with a hook and cut off its excess. 
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if contrary to this it is an artery or vein: then encircle it greatly.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation. 
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and insert into them two strong threads; and insert the two needles into the circle which you made around the apostema in the shape of a cross, making them penetrate. 
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then constrict the apostema in four places over the needles; and if you wish, remove the needles, and leave the place until the extended flesh putrifies; and falls off by itself; or cut it yourself when it softens and putrifies. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what is necessary from ointments until it heals.  
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	But if the prominence of the umbilicus is from raw flesh in it, or from moisture; then it is necessary to make concave apostemas, as we said. 
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And you should draw out the blood, or moisture, which you find in it.  
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then treat it with what strengthens the place. 
¶ De cura CANCRI.	Concerning the treatment of CANCER. 
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53. 
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken in the division of the species of Cancer, and how the way to its cure is with medicines; and we cautioned against it being treated with iron so as not to ulcerate it; and we spoke of Cancer generated in the womb, and the caution against its treatment. 
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes Cancer is in a place where its eradication is possible; such as Cancer which is in the breasts, or in the thigh, and those like it, from the limbs suited to extracting all of it; especially when it is beginning and small. 
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	But when it grows old, and is large, it is not necessary to approach it. 
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I myself have not been able to heal anyone from it; nor have I seen another before me who attained that.  
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation for it, when it is located as we said, is to precede and loosen the weak part from black bile several times. 
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then if you find the phlebotomy itself with manifest fullness. 
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the sick person with preparation, in which he will be placed during the operation. 
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then project into the Cancer hooks that are suitable for him. 
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then scoop it out from every side with the skin, according to examination, until nothing remains of its roots; and let the blood run, and do not cut it off quickly, rather press the places, and wipe away all thick blood with your hand, or with whatever instrument is possible there. 
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if the thick flow of blood from the incision of an artery or vein opposes you, then cauterize the vein until the blood is severed. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the remaining treatment until it is healed.  
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	Concerning the Treatment of Hydropsy.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter Fifty-Four. 
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have already narrated in the division of species of Hydropsy, and how the aggregation of water is made; and the signs of every species, and its cure with medicine.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is cured with iron is none other than the ascites species alone; and it does not approach the species tympanitis nor the hyposarcae species at all, for that is fatal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this kind of dropsy of the ear drum with medicine, and your medication has not been successful, then consider. 
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.
