Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	Therefore, if it is penetrating into the inner margin of the anus nearby, then pull the thread out of that hole: so that you insert your finger into the anus and pull out the end of the thread, and join the two ends together: and tighten both, and let it go for one or two days; and the more the thread falls into the flesh, tighten it well, until those pieces of flesh that are between the two ends of the thread fall off; then care for the wound until it is consolidated and healed.  
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	But if the opening of the fistula is not penetrating, then make it penetrate in any way that is prepared for you, unless it is very deep. 
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	For it is not fitting for you to do that because of a tear, lest you fall into it.  
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Then do as we said with it until it is healed. 
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	The shape of a spathulated spine with which the fistula is divided, whose curvature is very sharp, and the other part is not sharp, so that it does not fall into what is not necessary, as you see. 
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	On the stitching of hemorrhoids, from which blood runs from their incision: and the care of fissures.  
Caput LXXXI.	Chapter LXXXI 
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are hemorrhoids according to two types. 
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	For they are either within the anus, similar to bladders of coals or prunes; or as if they themselves are grains of a bean.  
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	And from them are small ones and large ones: and blood runs from them always, and it is one, and there are many.  
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	And they are outside the anus, and at its extremities. 
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	But these which are outside the anus are according to most few in moisture, from which runs a yellow water, or little blood with a constant flow; and they are according to the color of the body. 
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	And the treatment of that which is within the anus is, that you command the sick person to sit: and it should be pressed until the anus emerges, and the hemorrhoids appear to you. 
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore suspend them with hooks; or hold them with your fingernail.
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut into them at their roots. 
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	But if hooks are not retained in them because of their moisture and softness: then take them with a rough cloth, or with a swab made from double wool, and draw them out with your fingers. 
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut into them, and sprinkle over them after the incision certain hot powders, so that they stand in place of a cautery.
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what preceded in the chapter on cauterization. 
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with the remaining treatment until they are healed.  
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	But if the anus does not yield to protrusion, then give the sick person an enema in which there is a little mordant, so that it washes with what is in the anus, and yields to protrusion quickly when the sick person strains. 
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	But if the hemorrhoids are external from the anus, then their matter is light, easy: and it is like you should take them with your fingernail or take them with a hook, and cut into them.  
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we have said until they are healed. 
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And whoever recoils from incision with a knife, then it is necessary that you administer their suture in this manner. 
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take an unraveled thread and insert it into the eye of a needle. 
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw the thread upward and make it penetrate with the needle at its root on one side; and entwine the two ends of the thread in the lower part of the needle, so that they are parallel; and tighten the thread with a strong knot. 
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then tie the thread and withdraw the needle. 
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the threads, and leave one out of them; do not draw it tight so that excess blood may run from it. 
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place a cloth soaked in rose oil or carrot juice on top of it and put it over the wound; and instruct the patient to rest. 
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then leave him until it falls off.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When therefore the threads fall off, care for them with ointments and the remaining treatment until they are healed. 
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	Concerning the Care of Fisures.
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	For they often happen from the drying up of feces and constriction of nature. 
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When therefore they become hardened and medicine does not work in them; then it is necessary that you scrape them with a spatula point or with your fingernail until they become moist and the upper layer which prevents them from consolidating is removed. 
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for them until they consolidate as needed.
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	But if they do not consolidate; then repeat them with a more vigorous scraping than the first, until they bleed much and are flayed, then care for them until they are healed. 
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	Concerning the Treatment of Hemorrhoids Inverted and Not Inverted; and Threads Dry and Ants.
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter 82.  
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	Know that a hemorrhoid is nothing but a round knot according to the color of the body, similar to the head of a nail; and it happens throughout the body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and fingers; and pain arises from them upon walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	Therefore it is necessary that what is in the circumference of the clavicle be cut and be held with forceps, or with a hook, and be eradicated from its root. 
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then take care of that; and if you wish, cauterize it according to what preceded in its chapter. 
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	But from the dried athel one is a small eminence, rough, filtered, round above the surface of the body.  
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And they often occur in the hands of boys. 
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And its treatment is, that you extend the athel, and cut it; or you tie it with silk thread; or with a hair until it falls off.  
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what was previously mentioned with fire, or with a sharp medicine; and now inverted athel are eradicated, and those not inverted with the instrument that I shall say. 
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	Furthermore, a formica is also a small filtered eminence, thick, above the surface of the body, going deep; and when it finds cold, it feels like a ant bite and spreads throughout the body; and most of it occurs in the hands. 
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its treatment is that you take a cannula from a goose feather, or a strong vulture feather; and place the cannula over the formica until the circle of the cannula contains its parts. 
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then revolve your hand with the cannula until you cut what is in the circumference of the formica; and place it deep into the flesh, and eradicate the formica from its root.  
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, do that with a cannula of air, or iron, according to this form. 
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the cannula be drawn upward and covered, so that the apprehension on it is relieved and its rotation itself. 
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish, cauterize the formica according to what was previously mentioned in the cauterization of the athel in the chapter on cauterization. 
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	Of the forms of instruments which are employed for fistulas in diseases of the anus, and opening of the abdomen, and colic. 
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter Eighty-Three. 
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	Sometimes an enema is made of silver, or of brass, or of cast bronze, or hammered. 
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And sometimes it is made of these instruments small and large, according to those in which they are administered.  
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	Therefore that which is administered in the healing of very young children should be small; and those whose anuses are weak, or painful, so too their enemas. 
Clistere magnum.	A large enema.  
Cistere paruum.	A small enema. 
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The cane of it, that is, the upper head in which the bladder is tied, should be wide according to this manner; and let there be a distinction so that the bladder is tied as you see, and the lower extremity which is introduced into the anus should be deaf, that is, not open, smooth, very drawing towards subtlety: and on one side of it let there be two holes, and on the other side one hole. 
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And let the width of the hole be according to the thickness of the rays, and a little thicker; and let the bladder in which the medicines are placed be from an animal's bladder: or from sheepskin parchment, which should be according to the form of a small wineskin: whose root is one palm.   
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And let it be perforated with many holes as it is turned, and the space which is between every hole should be the thickness of a finger. 
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into those holes a strong thread from raw silk, which should be from ten threads or thereabouts, and join it with a bladder like a wineskin.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When therefore the bladder is placed in it, tie it tightly in the head of the enema between two distinct constrictions. 
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then administer the enema with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the shape of the circle bladders here depicted and their holes. 
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of giving an enema with it is: to fill a syringe or bladder from medicine which is warmed according to the amount tolerated by the sick person; and be careful that it is not very hot or very cold. 
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the sick person is laid on their back and raises their legs upwards; and put underneath them a mattress, that is, skin on which people lie, or a sheet. 
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then smear the end of the enema with oil, or with egg white, or with fenugreek mucilage, or similar things. 
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then insert it into the anus easily.  
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then let the attendant grasp the syringe with both hands together and squeeze it forcefully until they have emptied everything that is in the enema into the intestines. 
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then withdraw the enema, and let the sick person raise their legs to the wall. 
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	And if the medicine compels them to defecate, then they should hold it as long as they can.  
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if they sleep with it all night, it is better for healing. 
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if you give an enema to them in illnesses of abdominal dropsy, and their defecation is hurried; then repeat the enema until they are healed. 
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	But if there are hemorrhoids or painful abscesses in the anus, then let the enema be very subtle and gentle, from the enemas with which children are given enemas. 
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of a subtle enema for when the skin is tight.  
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the treatment of head wounds without bone fracture. 
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter 84.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already said in the division on the treatment of wounds what was appropriate for the book, and I will say here their treatment with the hand and with medicines according to supplementation. 
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	Therefore I say that wounds are diversified according to what they are done by and according to the place on which the wound falls.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	Therefore, the things by which wounds are often made are like the throwing of a stone: or a cut with a sword, or a knife; or a blow with a spear, or wood, or an arrow; and similar things from many objects. 
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	But wounds which are made according to the parts of the body are like a wound that falls on the head, or neck, or chest, or belly, or thigh; and similar ones from those limbs.  
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am relating the treatments of some wounds so that I may put this reasoning and rule over the remaining wounds. 
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with simple head wounds; because the recollection of compound ones will come at the beginning of the third chapter.  
Dico ergo.	Therefore, I say. 
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When a simple wound occurs on the head and there is no fracture of the bone; then consider if it is from the throw of a stone, or things similar to it, and has already broken only the skin; and the wound is large, and you fear for a bad outcome of hot abscess; then hurry and perform a cephalic phlebotomy immediately; and do not delay it; and draw out blood from him according to the quantity of his strength: if there is nothing forbidding phlebotomy, especially if the blood that comes out from the wound is little. 
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be from the opposite side of the wounded part. 
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the sick person beware for himself against repletion, and wine, and coarse foods.  
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	But if something forbids reduction, then let him reduce from food, and not approach meats, nor wines. 
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And put on the wound if a hot abscess happens to him, cotton infused in rose oil alone, or with wine in which there is astringency. 
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	But if you are safe from a hot abscess, then put on the wound, if it is fresh with its own blood and has not been changed by air, the powder which I will relate a little later: and if it has already been changed by air, then put on it certain ointments until it heals. 
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	But if the wound is large, or is from a cut by a sword, and similar weapons: and the lips thereof do not come together by stitches, then join it with suture, according to what I shall relate about wounds of the belly and their suturing. 
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	But if the wound has already been torn from the bone, and hangs down, and there is no retention of it except in a small suspensory, then cut it. 
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then treat the wound with medicines, and restore hard flesh in it in place of the skin, and instruct the sick person to nourish themselves with foods which have substance, such as heads, and cooked wheat, until they are plump; and those similar. 
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	And if you find putrefaction in the skin, and it does not adhere to the bone: then cut out all the putrefaction, and throw it away; then treat that [area]. 
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	But if in these wounds there is an artery, or vein from which blood flows: and it is not severed by medicines, then inquire above the artery. 
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If therefore you find it not cut, then cut it with a Spatula, or tie it off. 
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if necessity compels when that which we said does not apply, then cauterize it until the blood is severed. 
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	But if these wounds are small, simple, then their matter is easy, light: so that you sprinkle on them this powder: because it will consolidate them before they change in the air. 
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of Making Incarnated Powder.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part of frankincense, and two parts of dragon's blood, and three parts of unquenched lime: mix the whole well, and sift it; and fill the wound from it, and constrict it with a good constriction until it adheres well upon it, and coagulates with the blood. 
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then constrict it from above with stitches, and leave it alone; and do not loosen it until it remains, so that it does not discharge.  
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For it is not eradicated by medicine until it is healed. 
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And sometimes lime alone does this when you do not have frankincense at hand, and dragon's blood also makes the same operation in many large wounds, when it is suitable to put it on them and bind them up, and they are recent wounds with their own blood which has not been changed by air. 
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	But if the air has already changed it somewhat, especially when it is in the summer season, then the application of this powder is not in order; therefore care for it with what we have said, so that you put on it certain digestive ointments: or put on it poultices made from barley flour, made with water and honey, until they discharge pus. 
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the rest with further treatment until they are healed.  
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	But if it should happen that a fracture occurs in the bone with the wound, and it is small, then extract it with forceps; and I will already say the treatment of skull fractures in what is to come. 
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Of wounds of the neck. 
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter Eighty-Five. 
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	But if a wound should happen in the neck, then there is no difference in its treatment and that of a head wound when it is simple. 
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	But if a nerve or artery of the neck has already been cut: then if it is a nerve, there is no remedy for it except that its treatment be joined with that which produces strong astringency, such as alum and saffron, and those similar to them. 
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	For they injure nerves and contract them.  
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not put anything cold at all on the wound; for the substance of nerves is cold, and its continuation is with the brain, which is more sublime than other members; and let that with which it is treated be from mild medicines, such as lime slaked with fresh water repeatedly infused with oil, or with rose oil, and tutty when washed also with fresh water: and the remaining mineral stones in this manner, and soft ointments.  
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	If, however, the wound is large, then apply a suture; or bring its lips together with lint. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals. 
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	But if the wound has depth, or a sinus occurs in its lower part, in which pus already collects, then perforate it in a more depressed place within it. 
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	But if an artery has already been incised in the wound and its flow of blood follows: then separate or cauterize it, and bind it; or cauterize it, if necessity compels it to be done so.  
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	But if the spondyles of the throat have already fallen, or the whole thing, and the alhaudig are saved: then join the lips of the skin with a suture over the trachea, and do not touch the throat, rather equalize it, and return it to its natural form. 
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then constrict it with a decent ligature, and leave it for several days.  
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments which have astringency and desiccation, until it heals. 
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	But if the wound has already made an impression on the bone, then explore it: then if there are fragments of bone in it, extract them all, or as many as you can from them; and what is not prepared, leave it until the wound putrifies, and separates and relieves its exit.  
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	But if the wound is recent, then sprinkle over it the powder which I have described. 
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	But if bone appears to be seen in the wound and a fistula is formed: then treat it with what its recollection comes to in its chapter. 
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	On a Wound on the Fingers.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter Eighty-Six. 
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is a strike from a spear or knife and you see its depth, then consider it.  
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	But if windiness comes out from the wound, when a weak person breathes from it, then know that the wound is mortal. 
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it is not deep, and fresh with its own blood, then do not put powder on it from the first hour, nor bind it up, so that the blood may not be retained in its depth, and return to the heart, and kill the sick man; but apply an attractive ointment to it, and dissolve it twice a day. 
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	But if you do not have ointment at hand, then put an old rag in the opening of the wound, so that it may draw out what comes forth from it of moistures; and make the sick man sleep upon the wound, so that what is gathered in it may flow.  
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	But if three days or more have already passed since the wound, and there does not happen to the sick man spasm, nor evil trembling of the heart, nor constriction in breathing, and you see the remaining dispositions of his are good: then know that the wound is well. 
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Therefore take care of it with dressings, and other treatment, until it heals.  
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	But if its healing is excused, and it is now always open, then know that a fistula has already been made. 
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Therefore take care of it from its own chapter.  
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from a cut of a sword, or knife, and it is simple on the surface of the chest, or back: then take care of it with what preceded from suture, if it is large; or with powder, if it is small. 
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if it has already made an impression on the bone, and chips come out of it: then examine the wound, and hurry to extract those chips, if they are separate.  
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	But if they are not separate, then leave them until the wound putrifies, for their extraction is alleviated then. 
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	But judgment in the treatment of other accidents of wounds in the remaining limbs is the judgment that we have said. 
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Concerning wounds of the belly, and the exiting of intestines, and their issue. 
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter LXXXVII. 
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	Disruption which occurs in the abdomen is great, medium, and small. 
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	From a great disruption, therefore, sometimes intestines or a number of intestines protrude. 
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore their introduction is made, and their suture more vehement and difficult.  
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And even a small disruption is difficult in another way. 
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	It therefore follows that their reduction is more difficult if you do not hasten in introducing them to their place immediately; because it swells, opens, and enlarges; therefore its entry becomes difficult.
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Because of this, therefore, a medium disruption is better; because with it the reduction of the intestine is not difficult as it becomes difficult in these two species. 
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that the suture of a vein is according to four methods.  
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two sutures are common and apply to the suture of the abdomen, and to the suture of other wounds of the body; and two other sutures specifically pertain to the remaining wounds. 
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However, they are more appropriate with the suture of the abdomen; and I will explain each one to you with description and explanation. 
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say, therefore, that when a wound is small, and something protrudes from it out of the intestine, and it is difficult to reduce it; then this is due to one of two methods. 
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the disruption, as we have said; or because there is inflation in the intestine because of the cold air. 
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When therefore it is so, then you must warm it, so that you submerge a sponge or cloth moistened in lukewarm water alone.  
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or you boil in water fennel, papyrus, and saffron and embrace the intestine with it until the inflation is resolved. 
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	Sometimes it makes wine in which there is astringency; and it is better than water alone in resolving inflation.  
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When therefore you see the swelling already resolved, then moisten the intestine with water in which marshmallow or mullein has been boiled. 
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For through that its entrance is eased with a small thing. 
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	But if its return is excused after this treatment, then make a small incision in the disruption with the instrument with which hemorrhoids are cut. 
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first treatment is better when it is prepared than a section; and compulsion is not made to cut after necessity and lack of instrument. 
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part of it be twisted and sharp, and the other part not sharp, and let the subtle end not be with the subtlety of a spatula, rather let it be somewhat duller: and it is that which resembles a chisel, as you see. 
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When therefore the wound is enlarged and enters the intestine, then it is necessary that there be a reduction of it according to its own natural form in its proper place, if possible above it: for it is better. 
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When, however, the disruption is wide in the lower part of the belly: then it is necessary that you make the sick person lie on his back and put his legs higher than his head. 
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the belly, then put his head and chest higher than his lower parts. 
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And similarly if the disruption is in one of the two parts of the belly, then put your intention and your consideration always on this, that the part in which the wound is be higher than the other part. 
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And thus it is necessary that you administer it in large wounds and in middle wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But in small wounds, put it according to what is prepared for you. 
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make a pious minister be present between your hands who will hold the whole disruption with his hand and bring together its lips.  
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then uncover from it for him who follows a suture something after something; and this is the way of a common single suture.  
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And take a needle, or a sharp-pointed instrument, according to the size of the wound. 
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then let fall from the extremity of the disruption the width of a ring finger, that is, of a physician; and fix the needle one span beyond what you are about to introduce the thread into it in two places at the skin, with two extremities of sifac which is under the skin from within, until you make it penetrate from the other side, and you have now joined the two extremities of the skin and the two extremities of sifac; and there become four rows. 
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then tighten with a double thread around the needle several times on both sides at once, until the two lips of the wound are joined in a decent manner.  
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let fall the width of a finger also, and fix another needle into them; then draw it tight with thread, just as you did with the first needle. 
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Therefore do not cease doing that with as many needles as you need until you complete the constriction of the whole wound.  
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let the needles be of a medium size between thickness and thinness; for thin needles pierce the flesh very quickly, and thick ones are difficult to insert into the skin; therefore it is necessary that they should be medium in thinness and thickness. 
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not necessary that the needle be fixed in the two extremities of the skin very close together; lest the flesh be pierced quickly and the wound opened before its consolidation, and lest they also be elongated with the suture so as not to prevent the wound from consolidating. 
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut off the ends of the needles so that they do not injure the sick man in his sleep; and put little tufts of cloth on all sides to hold the ends of the needles; and leave them until you know that the wound is already consolidated. 
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this indeed, kind of suture with needles thus is more suitable for small wounds. 
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For it suffices in the suture of those, one needle, or two, or about that number.  
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second suture is common, so that the aggregates with the suture join the four ends: two ends of the skin and two ends of the sifac in one stitch, with a needle in which is wrapped a thread equal in subtlety and thickness. 
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have penetrated with the needle these four ends, draw back the needle from the part where you began, so that the drawn thread falls from the upper part of the wound; so that the suture is like the suture of cloth by which cloths are tied, and place between every suture an amount of thickness less than a finger. 
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	But men know this suture. 
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this suture I healed a wound that had happened to a man in his belly, who had been wounded with a knife, and the disruption of the wound was greater than one palm: and about two palms had come out from the intestines from the middle intestine, and the disruption was in the middle of the belly. 
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	I therefore returned it after his bowels had stood outside the wound for twenty-four hours. 
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	The wound was therefore consolidated in a space of about fifteen days; and I took care of it, and it was healed; and he lived after that for many years, converted to his own affairs. 
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the physicians had judged that it would not be healed. 
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And from a miracle it was, that I did not care for it with ointment.  
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	For I was in a place where ointment was not found, nor anything of medicine. 
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	Therefore I put old linen over the wound twice a day, and I diligently washed it with honey water until it was healed. 
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	But I shall tell two kinds of proper sutures according to the account of speech.  
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is, that you begin with a sharp suture; and you introduce the needle from the outer to the inner part. 
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When therefore the needle penetrates into the skin, and into the muscle going according to the length and breadth of the whole body: let the end of the sifac fall in the side in which you introduced the needle, and make the other end penetrate from the inner part to the outer part in the other end marvel.  
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When therefore you have made it to penetrate, then make it to penetrate thus in this same extremity, from the exterior part to the interior: and let go the extremity of the sifac, which is on this side, and make the point to penetrate into the other extremity from the interior part to the exterior; and make it to penetrate with your penetration that you make it to penetrate into the sifac extremity, which is in its part, until it penetrates into the whole. 
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then begin also from this same side, and draw it up with the extremity which is from the sifac on the other side, and extract the point from the skin which it has penetrated. 
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then return it to that skin, and draw the sifac extremity which is on the other side with this mirach extremity; and extract it from the skin which is from its part, and do that vice versa, one after another: and do that vice versa, until you have drawn out all its extrinsic part according to that example. 
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the sum of this suture is that its suture should be like the sutures of skinners, so that its sifac vice versa on one side with one extremity of skin; and that you should let it go vice versa on the other side, until you complete it.  
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of proper suture, which Galen mentioned. 
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	His speech is narrated so that its suture should be according to the similarity which some physicians have, in such a way that they bring together all the part to its fitting counterpart by nature: and they apply the sifac extremity to its other extremity, and the mirach extremity to its other extremity. 
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And that is done according to what I tell you. 
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	It is necessary that you fix the point into the mirach extremity nearest to you from the exterior part, and make it penetrate to the interior in that alone; and let go the two sifac extremities. 
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then turn the point, and make it penetrate from the exterior part to the interior into the two sifac extremities, namely on both sides. 
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn both, and also make both penetrate from the inside to the outside, into the two extremities of the other side. 
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of suture is better than the common easy suture, and it is the suture of which a reminder preceded. 
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is therefore also the speech of Galen. 
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some said. 
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture of the belly is corrected with two needles. 
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	Which is, to insert one thread into both of them; and begin with the insertion of the needle, from what is at your side, and make it penetrate up to the other side, according to the suture of those who are skins equally. 
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when the disruption is in the middle of the belly, then its suture is more difficult than that of the other places of the belly. 
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	But the judgment of the medication of a wound, is the judgment of other wounds.  
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	Which is, because when you obtain a fresh wound with its own blood, before the air changes it; and you reduce the intestine, and its own, and fit it; then place powder of incarnating on top. 
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	But if the air has already changed the wound: then place some ointments, which are present to you, on top of it until they make pus; and the threads fall off, and the sifac and mirach become consolidated. 
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it as is the care of other wounds, until it is healed. 
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if medicines are not present to you, then immediately place on it, from which it begins to emit pus, old cot; and change it twice a day, as I taught you, until it is healed. 
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need other medication in many dispositions, when the wounds are simple.  
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	But if you fear that the wound communicates to the principal members in injury, then it is necessary for you to immerse soft wool in oil of tempered heat, or in rose oil; and place it in the circumference of the places which are between the groins, and under the armpits.  
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain, or pricking, or putrefaction in his bowels (for this often happens) then give him an enema with dark, thick, warm wine; especially if the putrefaction has already reached the intestine and is about to penetrate to its cavity. 
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that what is from the large intestine is easier to heal; and what is from the small intestines is harder to heal. 
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	But the intestine which is called Jejunum does not admit healing from a wound that happens in it at all; and this is because of its multitude, which is of veins, and their size, and because of the subtlety of its body, and the proximity of its nature to nerves. 
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	But if what proceeds from the wound is a protuberance, and you obtain it fresh; reduce it according to your reduction, by which you reduce intestines equally. 
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if a space has passed for it, and it has already become green, or black; then it is necessary that you tie it with thread above the place which has been darkened from it, so that flow of blood does not occur. 
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in a protuberance are veins and arteries. 
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut what is beyond that ligament, and put two ends of the thread hanging from the lower part of the wound outside it; so that relief comes upon you from its attraction, and extraction of itself in case of the protuberance, and emission of pus from the wound. 
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Recollection of a Wound That Happens in the Intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When a rupture occurs in the intestine and it is small; then it is possible that it may be restored in some people: therefore, because I have seen one who was wounded in his belly with a thrust of a spear, and the wound was from the right of the stomach, and the wound was old; and a fistula was made, and there issued from it discharge, and flatulence.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	Therefore I applied treatment until I was no longer anxious about its healing; nor did I cease to dress it carefully until it was healed and the place consolidated. 
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw the place was already consolidated, I feared for the sick man, lest some evil accident should befall him in his belly; and no such evil accident befell him. 
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in a better state of health, eating and drinking, and sleeping soundly, and he entered the bath, and exercised himself in his daily routines. 
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And certain experimenters have now said that when a wound occurs in the intestine and is small, then it ought to be ligated in this manner. 
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is, that you should take ants of large heads.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound and place one ant with an open mouth upon the two lips of the wound. 
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When its head is thus upon them and it clenches its jaws, cut off its head; for it adheres and will not be loosened.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first and do not cease to do this with ant after ant according to the total extent of the wound. 
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then bind it up and its wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For those heads will remain attached within the intestine until the intestine is nourished and healed, and no harm will befall the sick man inwardly.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And it is now possible that the intestine may also be ligated with a fine thread; which has been drawn out from the intestine of an animal and attached to it after it has been introduced into a needle. 
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is, that you should take the end of this thread from the intestine and it should be scraped off very much. 
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then tie a fine linen thread around its end.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert that thread into a needle and sew the intestine with it.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then bind it up in its dressing. 
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of suture with thread and gut is not except according to the way of trust and hope. 
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that a wound which is large, wide, especially if it is in one of the slender intestines: then there is no skill except refinement, and there is no healing of it at all. 
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	On the treatment of fistulae and ulcers. 
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter Eighty-Eight. 
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Know that every wound or abscess when it grows old and becomes chronic, and becomes an ulcer, and does not consolidate, and emits pus always, and is not cut off: then it is called universally wherever it may be a fistula, and we call it a zulchemen. 
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula indeed is according to truth a knotted filtration, hard, white: with which there is no pain, which has the concavity of a bird's feather: and on account of that some call it risata, that is, a feather. 
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And it is in certain hours moist, which emits pus. 
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps the moisture is split in certain hours. 
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes this moisture is much, and is little: and it is thick, and it is subtle. 
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I already stated previously in the division, then when I said wounds, that every ulcer which does not heal, nor is flesh born in it, it is not except because of one of nine new causes. 
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	Of which one is, either because of the scarcity of blood in the body; or because of its malice; or because between it and on its lips there is hard flesh, prohibiting the birth of flesh; or because it is full of much filth and dirtiness; or because the ulcer in itself is putrid, and the material which is sent to it is of bad quality; or because the medicine is unsuitable in its treatment; or because corruption falling into the region is a pestilential kind; or through a property in the region, as happens in Caesaraugusta: in which digestion of illnesses becomes difficult, and healing of abscesses is delayed by nature; or because there is one bone, or a number of bones in it. 
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have already shown all these causes and their signs, and their treatments with medicines in the division; and it is necessary here for me to make you know the treatment of Fistula and Zuken, which is done by way of operation with the hand. 
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	Therefore know that Fistula occurs in all the members of the body. 
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For from them are Fistulas which reach the large veins and arteries, or nerves, or sinews; or to the intestine, or to the bladder, or to one of the ribs: or to one of the vertebrae of the back, or to one of the joints composed of composition; such as the hand, and foot: and from them are those which go to the proximity of the principal member, and similar ones.  
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Which therefore of these Fistulas is in this way, is from illnesses difficult of healing, and does not receive treatment, and occupation with it is toil and ignorance. 
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	But if it is from Fistulas some of whose depth does not reach these places which I said: and you hope, and trust in its treatment, and wish to arrive at the knowledge of it, then take a probe of bronze, or iron, if the Fistula tends according to straightness, and explore it with it. 
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	But if there is crookedness in the Fistula, then investigate it with a probe of thin lead.  
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	For lead because of the gentleness of its body is relieved, and curves around the crookedness. 
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	But if the Fistula has many openings, it is not possible for you to indicate over it with a probe.  
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore cleanse from them an opening out of its openings. 
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the moisture with which you cleanse it, goes towards the other openings, and runs from them.  
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then carefully inquire according to what way it is possible for you: that you may know that there is a bone, or nerve, and the Fistula's concavity is distant, or near: or that the Fistula is single which has many openings, and stand upon all of it, with your utmost strength: with inquiry on your part, by which you question the sick person, and discovery of pain at pressure with your hand upon the place, and similar ones from signs and causes happening to a boil. 
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have stood upon all these true stations, then go to the cure according to confidence: and it is, that you consider then, if there is a fistula nearby apparent, or in a safe place far from the joint, or from a nerve, or artery, or vein, or one of the places which I told you: then cut the fistula according to what has been said in my narration, and remove what is in it from filtration, and corrupt flesh, which is born in its orifice from flesh, or thelul, and similar things: and care for it until it heals. 
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	But if the fistula is of distant depth, and is according to straightness: then it is necessary that you cut it deeply as much as is possible for you. 
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then cleanse it from all its corrupt flesh. 
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer linen wrapped in sharp medicines: and insert it up to the concavity of the fistula which you comprehended with iron: do this repeatedly with it until the sharp medicine corrodes all that remains in the concavity of the fistula from corruption. 
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with ointments which generate healthy flesh until it heals.  
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	But if it does not heal through that, then cauterize it according to what we have narrated. 
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	Therefore if the cause of the fistula is a bone, and it is made certain to you: then inquire into it and cut it according to what I have narrated to you: if nothing prevents you from a vein, or nerve, or main member as we said. 
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If therefore the bone is revealed to you, and there is something of corruption and blackness in it: then scrape it until all its corruption is removed.  
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which makes flesh upon it until it heals. 
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	But if it does not heal and emits pus as it was doing: then know that you have not reached the total eradication of the corruption. 
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore reveal it again, and make a careful examination of it, and cleanse it with your ultimate strength. 
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it yourself. 
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	Therefore if it heals, it is good; and if not, then you will know that corruption is deep within the body, which you have not reached. 
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	Therefore there is no skill for you in it except to leave it to nature. 
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	But if the mouth of a young child is corrupted and it is possible for you, draw it out with fine forceps suited to it. 
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	But if there are many bones, then make a careful drawing out of them all, and do not leave anything behind with your strength. 
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	But if something opposes you from the humors and there is no fear or mistake in cutting them: then cut into those humors and flesh if they are there and free the bones. 
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	But if you do not have preparation for taking out the bones at your time, then place over the wound what will cause it to decay itself; and leave it until that which is around those bones decays from flesh and humors. 
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And see that the wound does not solidify. 
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let the incision which you made in your operation be tightened.  
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	Rather place over it, if you fear, a cloth steeped in sulfur ground with oil; or a cloth steeped in Egyptian ointment, or some emerald ointments. 
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those humors decay and separate from the bones, removal and their drawing out are eased.  
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	But if there is one large bone, such as the bone of the leg or the hip bone and similar to these, and what is corrupted from it is a large part; then scrape it with the last resort until that blackness and corruption are removed.  
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the wound. 
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	But if what is corrupted in it is a large part and the corruption has already reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to saw it and cut it all the way to the place where the corruption has reached; then care for it until it heals. 
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you about a man who had a wound on his leg: so that you may take it as an example and aid for your operation. 
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was a young man of about thirty years old, to whom pain occurred in his leg from a cause which had moved upon him within the body, that is, from within; until the matter reached his leg and there formed a large abscess: and he did not have an external cause. 
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	Time was extended with him in error of the physicians until the abscess was opened and much matter flowed from it. 
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And his treatment was postponed until his leg became fistulated and many openings were made in it; which all emitted pus and the body's humors. 
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	Many physicians treated him for about two years, and there was no one wise in the art of the hand among them until I was called upon and saw his leg and the materials which were flowing from those openings with a great flow: indeed, the whole body of the man had already wasted away, and his color was citron. 
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	Therefore I introduced a probe into one of the openings and it reached the bone.
