Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings and found that they reached each other from all parts of the leg.  
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I hastened then and cut above one of those openings until I exposed a part of the bone; and I found it corrupted, which had already been corroded and blackened, and putrefied, and was perforated until it penetrated to the marrow.  
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I sawed off what was revealed to me and prepared it from the corrupted bone. 
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I determined that there was nothing in the bone except that corruption which I had cut off and sawed.  
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And now I had eradicated it. 
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I placed the restoration of the wound with consolidating medicines over a long space.  
Et non est consolidatum.	And it did not consolidate. 
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I probed and found above the second opening, above the first discovery, a continuous corruption with bone; and I sawed what appeared to me also from that corruption. 
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I tried its restoration. 
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored. 
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	Therefore I discovered above it again and did not cease to cut the bone into pieces and try its restoration; and it was not restored until I cut about a palm from the bone and extracted it with its marrow. 
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with medications and it quickly consolidated and healed; and this iteration was not necessary in its operation and section except for the weakness of the sick person's constitution, and his lack of tolerance, and my fear for him regarding death: because he suffered from evil syncopes in all hours from excess evacuation. 
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was therefore healed with complete healing; and firm flesh grew in place of the bone, and a good arrangement was made in his body, and his strength returned; and he returned to his former conditions; and it did him no harm at all in walking. 
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the protruding bone in the body is already broken, then it is necessary to saw it according to this method; and it is: to take a ligament and tie it at the end of the protruding bone; and instruct someone to extend it upward; and put another ligament made of coarse wool after the first ligament. 
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then tie it over the flesh which is under the bone and extend its extremity so that you draw the flesh downwards; and you expose the flesh above the place which you wish to saw so that the saw does not injure the flesh.  
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board under the bone below decently; because when you do this, it is not prevented from cutting the corrupted flesh.  
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that the saw be over the corrupted place for a short time so that there is no corruption in the hollow of the bone; and it does not appear to the sense in its appearance and compels it to the vice of its own juice.  
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the mouth is corrupted and is not prominent but continues with its part, and the corruption is in its middle or in a part of it, then expose all the flesh from all sides. 
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood underneath. 
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then saw it from the first part, where the corruption is, until the saw continues on the other side; and let the saw be according to the length of the corruption a little further, as we have said. 
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	But if the corruption is at the junction, cut the corrupt junction itself, and saw the mouth where it continues on the other side. 
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if the corruption is in the continuation of two junctions, then there is no artifice in it except abrasion. 
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	But if the corruption is in the comb of the hand or in the comb of the foot, then the matter is very difficult. 
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary for you to inquire how the corruption appears to you. 
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And abrade it and cleanse it according to whatever arrangement is possible for you, and with whatever artifice is rectified for you: when it does not cause opposition to you by vein or nerve. 
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that there are many cutting and sawing instruments for cutting these bones, according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and subtlety, and magnitude, and smallness, and hardness, and rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that you prepare an instrument suitable for that operation of every species.  
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations signify to you above the kind of instrument with which you are in need when you have a long study. 
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of the methods of this art is a testimony to the methods of illnesses; for then you will already find by yourself what suits it from the instruments for every infirmity. 
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I affirm to you in the last of this chapter a number of instruments which you put examples on which you cut and a test by which you try on others. 
Forma Serrae.	Shape of a Saw. 
Forma alterius Serrae.	Shape of another Saw. 
Forma Serrae alterius.	Shape of another Saw. 
Forma Serrae alterius.	Shape of another Saw. 
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of a saw should be made carefully. 
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its upper arch be sharpness from iron; and let its handle be from boxwood, and let it be pyramidally made carefully.  
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Shape of a Scraper for Joining. 
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this scraper be according to the form of the head of a star-shaped nail; and let its points be according to the form of the points of an elishegife. 
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not fitting except that the heads of joins be rubbed with it when they are corrupted or when a wide and large mouth is present. 
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Shape of a Larger Scraper. 
Forma medii Rasorii.	Shape of a Medium Scraper.  
Forma Rasorii lati.	Shape of a Wide Scraper. 
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Shape of a Scraper in which there is a Concavity. 
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Shape of another subtle Scraper.  
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Shape of another scraper with a curved extremity. 
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Shape of a small, subtle tenaculum scraper. 
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Shape of a Scraper with which bones are incised. 
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Shape also of a large scraper. 
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a Rasp, and its extremity is like a Saw: it is exhibited in many places for the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Shape of a scraper which suits the reason of that which is perforated from bones.  
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its extremity is triangular, and its extremities are sharp. 
Fit ex Indi.	It is made from India.   
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly it is necessary that all which we have said be made from Scrapers and Cutters and Saws. 
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On the incision of extremities and the Locking of Bones. 
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter Eighty-Nine. 
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	Extremities putrefy either from an external or internal cause. 
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have treated that corruption with medical care, and the treatment does not help; and you see the corruption fall upon a limb which it does not affect: then it is necessary that you cut into that limb until you reach the corruption, so that the sick person may be delivered from death, or from the evil which is greater by the loss of the limb. 
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of this happening is that the limb becomes dark, until it seems as though fire has burned it, or it rots after the blackness: until that putrefaction is cut down to what follows that limb, and crawls into the whole body. 
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore hasten with the incision of it, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from the sting of certain venomous creatures: such as a sea scorpion, and viper, and asp, and the like.  
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption, or sting is in the extremity of a finger, then cut into the finger, and do not allow space for the corruption to advance as far as the rest of the hand. 
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut into it from the root of the forearm, and do not allow space for the corruption until it reaches the forearm. 
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades that, then cut into the arm at the elbow joint.  
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the corruption passes through, and you see it around the elbow: then death is upon the sick person. 
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And besides that from treatment, the quantity of strength is to be administered.  
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And do similarly with the foot, when corruption invades a toe, then cut it at one of the joints: and if it seizes the arch of the foot, then cut into the whole foot. 
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut the leg at the knee joint.  
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	And if the corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no wisdom in it except dismissal, and to leave the sick person to death. 
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	The manner of cutting a limb, or sewing it up, is to tie a ligature below the part you wish to cut and tie another ligature above the place. 
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	Let one assistant extend one ligature downwards, and let another assistant extend another ligature upwards. 
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between the two ligatures with a broad Spatula, until all the flesh is exposed.  
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it may be cut, or sewn up. 
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And you must place linen cloths on all sides, and let the saw not touch the healthy part; and it should happen that a weak additional injury is inflicted, and a warm poultice applied. 
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if internal bleeding should happen while you are operating, then cauterize the place quickly: or put some powders that staunch blood upon it. 
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is completed.  
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable bandage for it, and care for it until it heals. 
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that it happened to a man in his foot, the same accident that I am telling you about.  
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	Which is because a blackness occurred in his foot, with a burn that resembles fire's combustion; and that corruption first happened in his toe, until it began to affect the whole foot. 
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the man hastened from himself, after he saw the corruption cutting into his limb with its violence, which he found out from the pain and the burning of it; and he cut it at the joint, and was healed.  
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed for him, that same corruption happened to him in the index finger of his hand. 
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He therefore came to me, and I tried to recover that excess with what I put on his hand from medicines after the cleansing of his body; and the excess was not repelled, and it began to advance into another finger: until the corruption began in the hand.  
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He therefore called upon me to cut his hand; and I refused to do so, hoping that excess superfluity might pass from him on its own: and I also feared for him, lest he should die at the incision of his hand. 
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the man's strength was beyond the case. 
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	When therefore he despaired of me, he returned to his own land; and it was reported to me concerning him that, hastening, he fell upon his whole hand, and he was healed. 
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I have not related this narrative except that it may be a help concerning what falls upon the nature of this illness; and that it may be a sign by which it is signified, and according to which it is acted.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the Treatment of Sinuses, and the Quality of Clysters with Medicines. 
Caput XC.	Chapter Ninety.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in certain fleshy members and the space of the abscess extends until it collects pus; then it bursts or is perforated, and what is in it issues forth as pus, and a vacant place remains as if it were a vessel: and the skin that is over it is like a cloth that has already been attenuated: and the corruption does not proceed to its final stage, nor does it press into the mouth, nor into a nerve, nor into a ligament; it deserves to be called a Sinus and not a Fistula. However, if the space of it extends until the corruption presses into any one of these members, then it is called a Fistula or a zuken.  
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its treatment is to cut all that skin as it revolves; and especially when it has become attenuated and made like a cloth; and you trust because it does not adhere to the place on account of its corruption. 
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere and the last corruption does not follow from it; and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh, then treat it with a clyster; and it is, that you consider the Sinus. 
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that is emitted from it is of a foul odor: then cleanse it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, and oil, and ziniar, taking equal parts, mix them in a vessel; and decoct them over fire until the medicine reddens; and comes to the thickness of honey. 
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it as much as you need; and dissolve it with water and honey, and cleanse the Sinus with it; and constrict its opening, and let the medicine remain in it for the space of two hours. 
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with pressure; do this for as many days as necessary until the Sinus is cleansed and the foul odor is removed. 
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes cleanse with ash water, when you do not have this medicine present; and it is such that you should take ash from vine wood, or ash from holly wood; and pour water over it.  
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then strain it, and cleanse with it until you are confident that the Sinus is already cleansed. 
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	And if the weak person cannot tolerate Egyptian medicine nor ash water, then cleanse it with water and honey, to which some crushed ziniar has already been mixed. 
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or cleanse it with honey and wine mixed together, since honey has the property of cleansing and washing; and wine makes the Sinus adhere, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in the wine. 
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this several times, and are confident that the Sinus corruption has already been removed; then cleanse it with something that promotes flesh growth in it.  
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is such that you should take some dyafinicon plaster; and dissolve it with rose oil and astringent wine; or cleanse it with certain medicines, and other ointments, the properties of which I have written in the treatise on ointments.  
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	And if the opening of the Sinus is narrow, in which the enema cannula does not fit: then widen it a little with iron; or place in it a licorice root wrapped in Egyptian ointment, or basil ointment until it widens.  
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the orifice is also wide, then bring together its lips with suture: and let out from it a quantity into which an enema may enter without addition. 
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the orifice from which pus flows is raised upwards: then dry it up in a lower place which is in it so that pus may flow from it downwards: because pus when constricted in the depth of the sinus prevents flesh from being generated in it. 
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	And if it is not possible for you to dry up the sinus approximately below it according to your wish: then try, so that you prepare the limb with preparation so that pus may flow from it easily according to how it is prepared for you.  
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try so that nothing of the pus is retained in it at all: and take consolidating medicines which are put upon a sign, suitable to what you wish. 
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them upon linen cloth. 
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such quantity that communication of the whole sinus is made.  
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps a hole straight in the orifice of the sinus, a little wider than the orifice of the sinus. 
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from soft ointments upon another cloth according to the quantity of the hole: and put it upon that one in a position distant from the orifice of the sinus so that the flow of pus from it may be relieved: and do not remove the large cloth except after several days at once.  
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But the one which is upon the orifice of the sinus is the one which you remove every hour so that what collects in it from pus may exit: and so that you may know whether what flows from it is much or little: or digested or undigested. 
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this again consider the place of the sinus itself whether the master thereof feels pain in it or there is no pain in it: and whether there is an abscess in it or not. 
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your medication proceeds thus, and you see the matter which flows out upon the orifice of the sinus: then you will know that the sinus is already adhering or approaching adhesion: then therefore dissolve it in the morning or on the third day: and when you dissolve the wound then change another cloth and renew the ointment. 
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if after a long time a subtle virus comes out of the sinus, then do not despair of its adherence, for its healing is approaching, since there are some people who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and there are others who act contrary to that. 
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if after many days purulent matter undigested comes out of the sinus, then you will know that the sinus does not adhere. 
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	Therefore if the adherence of the sinus is delayed and its matter prolonged: then add to its drying medicines, so that they may be humid in their substance and dry in their power, such as diaphicinum ointment, when an excess of addition from zegi is added to it. 
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And of the last things by which it is cured, is to take diaphicinum ointment and dissolve it with rose oil, and pour over it old wine equal in its substance. 
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then mix it with that and use it. 
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And honey, when you boil it until it thickens, and use it, now does a similar action to this, when diaphicinum ointment is not present to you.  
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh and aloe and frankincense: grind the whole thing and sprinkle it over honey while it is over the fire. 
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then put a cloth over it and bind it over the sinus: and smear with the honey that you have boiled until it has thickened: and sprinkle spices over it, and put a cloth over it and bind it.  
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes long aristolochia is administered in it, and the roots of the lily and there is a lily: and herb flour, and centaury. 
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simply or combined, grind them, and sift them through a sieve: and sprinkle over the honey that I have described, and use it. 
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	But if the matter of the sinus is prolonged and does not heal by this treatment, then know that there is corruption in its depths: or it is already making an impression on the bones, or on the remaining hard members, or ligaments: then cure it with the treatment for fistulas, according to what has been previously stated.  
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	On the treatment of whitlow and a crushed nail, and cutting into an added finger, and sectioning. 
Caput XCI.	Chapter Ninety-One. 
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Whitlow is an abscess that arises beneath the nail of the thumb of the hand or foot; and perhaps it arises in the remaining fingers. 
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	Therefore when the matter thereof prolongs, and its care is neglected, and it becomes inflamed with a hot abscess; or it corrupts, and emits pus, until it corrodes the root of the nail; and perhaps it corrupts it altogether, and perhaps the corruption reaches the bone, until it has a foul odor; and the extremity of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark. 
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you treat it, as we said in the division, and your treatment does not succeed; then it is necessary that you cut with an iron the whole superfluity which remained from the nail. 
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that. 
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For the cautery is very helpful.  
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	But if the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the empty additions of the nail already compress the flesh inwards, and begin to prick it, and injure it: then it is necessary that you place a thin Radium under an angle of the nail which pricks the flesh, and push it upwards; and cut into the flesh with ease, and place upon what remains of the flesh from burning medicines, corrosive ones, until all of it is removed. 
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments until it heals.  
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	But if the corruption already presses into the bone, then it is necessary that you cut into the bone, and extract it; for it never heals while a corrupted bone remains in it. 
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	And if you see the erosion and corruption advancing into the finger, then cut it at one node, according to what has been previously mentioned about it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals. 
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, attrition or percussion should befall a nail, and there should be intense pain in it, then it is necessary first to let blood from a weak person. 
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp spatulum and make a transverse cut upwards. 
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful that the cut does not reach the flesh which is under the nail, for you will cause intense pain through it to a weak person, and it will be the cause of added growth of flesh in that place. 
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then treat the place with something that relieves pain. 
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	An added finger that is born in some men's hands, perhaps it is all fleshy; and perhaps there are bones in some of them; and perhaps there is a nail on it; and some of them are born at the root of a joint, or its birth is in some knots of the finger.  
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, the one that is born in some knots of the finger does not move; and the one that is born at a joint of the finger perhaps moves.  
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, the section of the fleshy one of these is easy. 
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	Which is to say, you should cut it off at its root with a broad spatulum.  
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the treatment of the one whose birth is at the root of a joint is difficult. 
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore abstain from cutting it.  
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But in the one that is born in a finger at the last knot, then you must first cut its flesh with a round incision down to the bone. 
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then saw the bone with one of those saws suitable for that purpose.  
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals. 
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Consolidation that happens between the fingers often happens either from the birth of a man, that is, he is born with it, or from consolidation of a wound, or from burning by fire and similar things. 
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, it is necessary to separate that consolidation until the fingers return to their natural form. 
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place cloths between them, or cloths soaked in rose oil, so that they do not join quickly and separate them; or put a thin sheet of lead between them until the place is consolidated as needed. 
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if a consolidation happens to some fingers with the palm, then cut that consolidation according to what is prepared and suits the shape of the limb. 
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Concerning the Incision of a Blemish.  
Caput XCII.	Chapter Ninety-Two. 
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Varicose veins are large, full veins affected by excess melancholic humors which occur in many parts of the body; and their occurrence is most common in the legs, especially in the legs of travelers, workers, and carriers. 
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary that you administer a strong flogging with a black whip several times. 
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then phlebotomize the patient from those veins.  
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of them with iron is according to two methods. 
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they are cut and black blood is extracted. 
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is that the vein is raised and entirely removed.  
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section of it is according to this method. 
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	First embrocate the leg with plenty of hot water until the thick feculent blood is resolved.  
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the infirm's leg from the upper part of their hip to the lower part of the knee with a bandage. 
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three, with a wide incision. 
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then raise it, that is, draw the blood into your hand from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and the phlebotomist should first phlebotomize the infirm person at the top. 
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut the vein further down until a quantity of blood comes out which you see is sufficient and which the strength of the infirm person can tolerate. 
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind it; and order him to abstain from foods that produce black bile; and repeat evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full, and this is harmful to the weak one. 
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	Its elevation however is in this way. 
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the leg of the sick person, if there are many hairs on it. 
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce it into a bath; or embrocate it on his leg with hot water, until it reddens and the veins swell; or exercise it with strenuous exercise, if a bath is not present for him, until the limb heats up. 
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin directly at the vein section lengthwise; or at its last part near the knee, or in its lower part near the heel.  
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with hooks, and expose the vein from all sides, until it appears to the senses; and at its appearance, you see it reddish towards a dark decline. 
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When therefore it comes out of the skin, you see it white as if it were a chord.  
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert a trocar beneath it until it is raised and comes out of the skin; suspend it with a blunt hook, gentle one. 
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then make another incision near that incision with three fingers.  
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then expose the skin from the upper part of the vein, until it appears. 
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then raise it with trocars as you did, and suspend it with another hook, as you did at first. 
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then make another incision, or several more incisions, if it seems necessary to you.  
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then raise it and cut it with the last incision near the heel. 
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then extract it to the incision that is above it.  
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you extract it from the incision that is above, or higher incisions altogether, until it comes out completely; then cut it. 
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you to be drawn out and raised: then introduce a needle with a strong double thread, and tie it, and draw it out; or introduce a radium under it, and turn your hand in every direction until it comes out. 
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware that it does not fall in. 
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it falls in, it becomes difficult for you to raise it greatly, and harm comes upon the weak one from it. 
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have drawn it all out, then place wool soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil over the place of the wound, and care for it until it is healed. 
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	But if the thorn is contracted, having a twist with an involution to the parts, and is not as we said according to straightness: then it is necessary that you split it above it on every part of its twist, and the places of its involution. 
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with hooks until you raise it all; and beware at your section above it that you do not fall upon a vein, or wound it; for it will become difficult for you to raise, or draw it out.  
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore preserve your prudence. 
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The Form of a Falling Thorn by Which It Is Healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of a blind thorn. 
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It does not have a curvature like the other thorns, nor is it of a sharp point, so that it does not wound a vein; and it is of a thick, gentle flexuousness; for if it were slender, it would fall upon a vein by its slenderness: but rather let it be excessively thick as we said. 
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the Extraction of a Vein of the Leg.  
Caput XCIII.	Chapter Ninety-Three. 
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in hot lands, such as Al-Andalus and the land of the Arabs, and in dry, hot lands of little tenderness; that is, those in which grass, nor trees are born.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it arises in other places of the body besides the legs. 
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation indeed is from putrefaction which occurs under the skin, just as snakes and ascaris worms occur within bodies, and worms generated between the skin and flesh. 
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this event of this Vein is, that a vehement inflammation occurs in the leg. 
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place blisters.  
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the Vein begins to come out from the place of that blistering, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal. 
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	Therefore when its extremity appears from it, it is necessary that you wrap upon it a piece of lead, whose weight is from one drachma to two drachmas, and bind it firmly: and let the lead hang suspended from the leg. 
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever therefore anything comes out from it to the outside, wrap that in lead and bind it.  
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	And if it is prolonged much, then cut a part of it, and wrap the remainder. 
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it entirely before it all comes out.  
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it, it contracts and enters into the flesh: and it causes an abscess to occur, and putrefaction in the place, and a bad ulcer.  
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary that it be handled gently and be drawn out gradually until it comes out from its last part, and nothing remains from it in the body: and from this indeed Vein there comes out in some men what is in its length five palms and ten. 
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And it has already come to me that it came out of a man twenty palms long.  
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it happens to you in the hour of your medication: then insert a ray into its foramen, and pierce it with a long foramen, along with its body, until all that is in it from matter is evacuated: and administer putrefaction to the place with medicines for several days.  
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care of it with the treatment of abscesses. 
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And indeed this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the junction of the foot, or in the foot itself; and it has many openings, and a branch goes out from every opening. 
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore care for it as we said in the division, and with that which was stated before.  
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Concerning the cutting out of worms generated under the skin, and it is called bovine disease. 
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter Ninety-Fourth. 
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is called Bovine Disease in a certain land among us; because it very often happens to oxen, and it is a small worm that is born between the skin and flesh. 
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it wanders throughout the whole body, ascending and descending; and it is shown to the senses by its movement from limb to limb, until it bursts wherever it bursts in the skin and comes out. 
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the putrefaction of certain humors.  
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just as worms and snakes happen, that is, earthworms and roundworms in the belly. 
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared because of its harmfulness.  
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it wanders through the body and rises to the head and reaches a place, then perhaps it opens there and comes out and destroys the eye; and that happens very often. 
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore you wish to cure it and extract it, then it is not done except when it wanders and appears to the senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore it is necessary that you tie what is above it and what is below it with a strong ligature constriction. 
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it and extract it. 
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	But if it burrows into the flesh and you do not find it: then place a cautery with fire upon the spot until it dies. 
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And the greater thing that is feared is its corruption, by which it corrupts the eye as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If however you see that it has already reached the head near the eye, then bind a good ligature under it above the eyebrow. 
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it and extract it. 
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the sick person use cleansing of his body with medicines dissolving foul and bad humors. 
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods generating putrefaction. 
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	Concerning incision for the ailment Nakir.  
Caput XCV.	Chapter Ninety-Fifth. 
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This ailment is called in our land Nakir, and it is a pain which occurs in certain members, then it is transformed from member to member. 
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have indeed already seen it, according to what I relate to you.  
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was summoned to an infirm woman in certain ulcers. 
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	She exposed her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm cord.  
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I remained for an hour, I saw one swelling advance with a burning sensation, just as a worm advances, ascending to her shoulder faster than it is possible: so that it is like living silver, when it runs from place to place.  
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore the pain withdrew from that place and was fixed in the shoulder. 
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour and it ran through the rest of the body until it reached the other arm.  
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she narrated to me that it revolved throughout her whole body, according to what I saw. 
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	Therefore I marveled at the swiftness of its transformation from member to member.  
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed before that, I had not seen this ailment with my own eyes in such a manner.   
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I saw many who found pain to be transformed from member to member, and I did not see it with my own eyes as I saw it in the woman. 
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that it is anything but because the woman was from those who are of dry bodies with exposed veins, therefore that swiftness appears to the senses.  
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they not appear according to this method in those who are delicate and have moist bodies, hidden veins. 
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	Therefore when you wish its cure and the patient feels that pain: then if it appears to you by eye as we said, then bind above it and below it quickly: and cut above it until that wind shall go out constricted: and cauterize the place. 
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see it with your own eyes: then treat it with shaking of the body and with that which expels winds and drives them out with foul pills and pills of Serapina and similar ones. 
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	Concerning the Extraction of Arrows.  
Caput XCVI.	Chapter Ninety-Six.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are diversified according to their kinds and according to the places in which they fall from the body. 
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their diversity is this: since some of them have large points and small ones: and concave ones and deaf ones.  
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And some of them have three angles. 
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And some of them have tongues. 
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And some of them have stars. 
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those which are according to the limbs in which they fall are according to two ways.  
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For either the limbs are from the principal concave limbs such as the brain and heart and liver and lung and kidneys and intestines and bladder and those similar to them.  
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	Therefore when it falls into any of these limbs and the signs of death appear to you which I will tell you after then it is necessary that you avoid the extraction of that arrow from them for death follows him in whom it is in many dispositions. 
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these evil signs do not appear to you and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the limb then draw it out and care for the wound. 
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For the signs of the brain when an arrow falls into it and penetrates the mouth and exits through the nasal passage which is above the brain are: because vehement spasms and dimness of vision and vertigo and redness in the eyes and swelling and redness of the tongue and spasm and confusion of mind and vomiting with cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will issue from the nostrils, or ears. 
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed. 
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And there issues from the place of the wound a white moisture like pus. 
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And there comes forth from it something like the wateriness of flesh.  
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear to you, then abstain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not come forth. 
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow when it falls into the heart are that it is near the left nipple; and he feels as if it were fixed in a hard thing, not in a hollow thing. 
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow has a motion similar to the motion of the pulse; and black blood flows from the wound. 
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And following that is coldness of the extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting.  
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore that death descends without doubt. 
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow when it has wounded the lung is the exit of frothy blood from the wound; and the vessels which follow the neck become inflamed, and the color of the sick person changes.  
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out a great, deep sigh; and he seeks the attraction of cold air. 
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	But if the arrow falls into the membrane which is in the chest, then it is near the small ribs; and there is a great panting with violent pain, with a sigh; and all the limbs of the shoulders are moved. 
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested from food will issue from the wound.  
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the belly and is fixed there, something like dung will issue from the wound, or phlegm, or intestine which has already been broken.  
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore there is no hope in its treatment, nor in the extraction of the arrow.  
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	But if the arrow falls into the bladder, and urine comes forth; and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is stronger upon the sick person: then know that it is mortal.  
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining limbs, such as the face, neck, throat, shoulder blade, armpit, vertebrae of the back, collarbone, hip, thigh, and similar limbs are saved according to multiple arrangements: when the arrow does not find an artery or nerve; and the arrow is not poisonous. 
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I have seen about these arrows so that you may understand through it concerning your treatment. 
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Which is this, because an arrow fell to a certain man in the tear duct of his eye, at the root of the nose. 
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore I extracted it from him on the other side, under the fat of his ear; and he was healed, and no harm befell his eye. 
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen to him in the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid; and the arrow was already concealed, and I did not obtain from it except a small part of it with which it adheres to its wood; and it was a large arrow from the arrows of Turkish bows, with soft iron, in which there are no ears. 
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	Therefore the Jew was healed, and no bad accident befell his eye.  
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian. 
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabic arrow, and it is the one which has ears. 
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	I therefore made a cut above it between two folds; and it was already submerged in his throat. 
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	Therefore I proceeded delicately with it until I extracted it, and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man which had fallen into his belly; and we thought that he would die from it. 
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed him, and nothing changed in his condition, I made a cut above the arrow; and I devised something about it, and extracted it; and he was healed, and no bad accident befell him. 
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man to whom an arrow had fallen on his back, and the wound had healed over it. 
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	Seven years afterward, the arrow emerged from the root of his hip. 
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom an arrow had fallen on her abdomen, and the wound healed over it, and the arrow remained inside her: and nothing changed in her disposition, and the woman did not find harm from it in any of her natural operations. 
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man to whom an arrow had fallen on his face: and the wound healed, and it remained, not finding much pain from it: and similar things to these many. 
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from a man of the King's princes, which had fallen to him in the middle of his nose, and was now inclined toward his right side a little: and the arrow was entirely concealed.  
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore summoned for his treatment after the fall of the arrow up to three days. 
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the wound of the arrow very tight.  
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I therefore inquired for it with a subtle probe, and did not feel it; and he himself indeed found a puncture and pain under his right ear. 
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore hoped that this puncture was from the extremity of the arrow.  
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore plastered the place with a plaster in which there was attractive and digestive power, trusting within myself that the place would become inflamed and the sign of the arrow would appear to me, so that I might cut above it: and nothing happened in the place indicating that the arrow had reached the location. 
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I therefore persisted with the plaster upon him for many days: and nothing happened, and the wound meanwhile healed: and he remained weak about its extraction for a space of days, until he felt the arrow one day within his nose. 
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he related this to me.  
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I therefore placed sharp, corrosive medicine upon the wound for many days, until it opened; and when I probed it, I felt the slender extremity of the arrow adhering to the wood. 
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound through that sharp medicine until the extremity of the arrow appeared visibly to us; and it took me about four months with this. 
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound was enlarged and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it and move it, and it did not yield to coming out: then I did not cease to refine and contrive upon it with various ingenious methods until on a certain day I began upon it with forceps skillfully made, according to how their form will come at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.  
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound. 
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And physicians indeed judge that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.  
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore I restored it and the wound became consolidated and he was healed with perfect health: and nothing harmed him at all. 
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I relate to you the quality of extracting certain arrows so that you may establish a rule and meaning upon that which I have not said. 
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Because the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended with narration; nor does this book comprehend it, and a prudent craftsman compares a little with much; and with that which is present, with that which is absent; and he finds a new operation and a new instrument among the descents of these foreign matters of this art when they happen. 
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not come out from the limbs in which they are fixed except according to two ways.  
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Either by attraction from the place from which it entered. 
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or contrary to the other part.  
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out from where it entered is either an arrow proceeding into a fleshy place and it is attracted and comes out.  
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	And if it does not yield to coming out at the hour in which it falls: then it is necessary that you let it alone for several days until the flesh which is around it putrefies and its attraction is relieved and its exit.  
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And likewise if it is fixed in bone, and does not yield to you for removal, then leave it also for several days: and repeat it with attraction and motion every day, until it comes out. 
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	But if it does not yield to you for removal after several days, then it is necessary that you perforate in the circumference of the arrow in the bone itself from every part with a fine awl, until the arrow is enlarged. 
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out and extract it. 
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head, and has already passed into one of the ventricles of the brain, and some of those accidents which I have mentioned appear from weakness: then abstain from drawing out the arrow, and leave it until its being equals after several days.  
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the sifach, then death is not prolonged for him. 
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed except in the body of the bone only, and does not penetrate as far as the sifach: and he remains weak for several days, and nothing happens to him from those accidents: then apply yourself to drawing out the arrow and extracting it.  
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed very firmly and does not yield to you for drawing: then administer awls around the arrow as I have described above: then care for the place until it heals. 
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow is already concealed in a place in the body and hidden from sensation: then inquire for it with your hand. 
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with certain instruments which are suitable for drawing it. 
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot get hold of it because of the constriction of the wound and because of the length of the arrow deep inside: and there is neither bone nor nerve nor vein there: then probe over it until the wound is enlarged and it is possible to extract the arrow. 
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	But if there are ears by which it is held, then free the flesh fixed in them from every part with all your skill: and apply yourself, if it is not possible to get hold of the flesh in the fracture of the ears and their twisting until it comes out. 
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.
